THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Clearwater Trust and Russell B. Lentz Trust, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Boyd G. Bunting and Media General Communications, Inc., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26108
Reheard November 30, 2005 - Filed February 6, 2006Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Marshall Winn, Wallace K. Lightsey, and Troy A. Tessier, all of Wyche, Burgess, Freeman & Parham, of Greenville, for Appellants.
        Brent O. Clinkscale and Heather Ruth, both of Womble, Carlyle, Sandridge & Rice, of Greenville, F. Dean Rainey, of Greenville, and Leslie H. Weisenfelder, of Dow, Lohnes & Albertson, of Washington, D.C. for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  This is an appeal from a circuit court order dismissing appellantsâ€™ amended complaint alleging breach of fiduciary duty and securities fraud pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss must be based solely upon the allegations set forth in the complaint.Â  Carolina Care Plan, Inc. v. United Healthcare Services, Inc., 361 S.C. 544, 606 S.E.2d 752 (2004).Â  The question is whether, viewing the allegations in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, the complaint states any valid claim for relief, even if the court doubts that the plaintiff will prevail.Â  Id.
FACTS
The amended complaint alleges that the appellants are trusts which owned stock in a closely held corporation known as Spartan Communications, Inc. (Spartan).Â  Respondent Bunting was an officer of Spartan, and is alleged to have been a shareholder in the corporation and an â€œinsider.â€Â  Appellantsâ€™ representatives consulted Bunting when deciding whether to sell some of their Spartan stock, and he reassured them that â€œthere was no contemplation, consideration, discussion or activity within Spartan relating to a possible merger, sale, or other transaction concerning Spartan or its stock up to that point.â€Â  Prior to these conversations, Bunting had told the beneficiaries of the trusts that Spartan would prefer them to sell any Spartan stock to the corporation rather than â€œoutsidersâ€ in order to keep it within the close corporationâ€™s â€œfamily.â€Â  In addition to alleging that Bunting was an officer, shareholder, and insider of Spartan, the complaint alleges that Bunting attended shareholder meetings and occasionally drove a beneficiary of one of the trusts to these meetings.
The complaint alleges that Bunting knowingly made false and misleading affirmative representations that no changes were contemplated at Spartan, and that in reliance on his representations the appellants sold some of their shares (2,300) back to Spartan at $200/share.Â  
Approximately six months later, in December 1999, Spartan announced its merger into respondent Media General.Â  When the merger was consummated in March 2000, all Spartan shareholders received approximately $800/share.Â  Had the appellants retained the 2,300 shares sold back to Spartan in May and June 1999, appellant Clearwater Trust would have received an additional $660,000 (approximately) and appellant Lenz Trust would have received $720,000 (approximately) more.
The complaint alleged four causes of action.Â  Three were directed to both Spartan and Bunting: breach of fiduciary duty, breach of fiduciary duty-unjust enrichment, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  One was directed to Spartan alone, and alleged a violation of the South Carolina Securities Act, specifically S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-1210(2) (Supp. 2004).Â  The circuit court held that Â§ 35-1-1210 does not create a private cause of action, and concluded that appellantsâ€™ three other claims alleged a single wrong, and that this claim arose under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-8-420 (1990).Â  The circuit court held this claim was precluded by the two-year statute of limitation found in Â§ 33-8-420(e), and granted respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss.
ISSUES
On appeal, appellants raise the following issues:

  (1)  Whether there is a private cause of action pursuant to Â§ 35-1-1210?
  (2)  Whether Â§ 33-8-420 codifies common law causes of action against a corporate officer who owes a fiduciary duty to a party separate and apart from his status as an officer?
  (3)  If Â§ 33-8-420(e) applies, what is the statute of limitations where the officer is alleged to have fraudulently concealed his breach of fiduciary duty?

ANALYSIS
I.  Private Cause of Action
Appellantsâ€™ third cause of action alleged Spartan committed fraud and deceit in purchasing appellantsâ€™ stock, thereby rendering it liable under the Securities Act, Â§ 35-1-1210(2).Â  Appellants argue the circuit court erred in dismissing this claim.Â  We hold the claim was properly dismissed.

  Section 35-1-1210(2) makes it unlawful for any person:
  
    in connection with the offer, sale, or purchase of any security, directly or indirectly, to:
    â€¦
    (2) make any untrue statement of material fact or to omit to state a material fact necessary in order to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which they are made, not misleading; or
    â€¦.
  

Appellants acknowledge that this Court has held that there is no implied private cause of action for aiding and abetting fraud under Â§ 35-1-1210, but argue that decision does not answer the question whether there can be a direct private action under the statute.Â  See Atlanta Skin & Cancer Clinic, P.C. v. Hallmark Gen. Partners, Inc., 320 S.C. 113, 463 S.E.2d 600 (1995).Â  They also concede that the Court of Appeals has stated in dicta that there is no such private right, see Garrett v. Snidegar, 293 S.C. 176, 359 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 1987), and acknowledge that in another appeal decided by this Court, the appellant conceded the issue.Â  Carver v. Blanford, 288 S.C. 309, 342 S.E.2d 406 (1986).Â  Appellants point out that these cases were all decided prior to 1997, when S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-510 (Supp. 2004) was amended, and argue this amendment evidences the General Assemblyâ€™s intent to create a private cause of action under Â§ 35-1-1210.Â  
In Atlanta Skin, the Court stated that the primary statute creating a private cause of action under the Securities Act is Â§ 35-1-1490, which imposes liability on sellers of securities.Â  The Court held that while Â§ 35-1-1210 makes â€œfraud or deceit in [securities] offers, sales, or purchases â€œunlawful,â€ [it does] not, by itself, create a private cause of action.â€Â  Id.Â  at 119, 463 S.E.2d at 603.Â  Contrary to appellantsâ€™ contention that Atlanta Skin only decided the aiding and abetting question, it held there was no private action under Â§ 35-1-1210.Â  
Appellants rely on a post-Atlanta Skin amendment to Â§ 35-1-510.Â  This section authorizes the securities commissioner to â€œrequire registered broker-dealers, agents, and investment advisors[1] who have custody of or discretionary authority over client funds or securities, to post surety bondsâ€¦Every bond shall provide for suit thereon by any person who has a cause of action under Section 35-1-1210â€¦.â€Â  While this statutory amendment may be read to give rise to a private cause of action under Â§ 35-1-1210, such a private action exists merely to the extent the alleged violator has posted a surety bond under Â§ 35-1-510.Â  Here, there is no allegation that a â€œ510 bondâ€ has been required or posted, and thus Â§ 35-1-510 does not support a finding that these appellants have a private cause of action under Â§ 35-1-1210.Â  This cause of action was properly dismissed pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6).Â  Carolina Care Plan, supra.
II.  Applicability of Â§ 33-8-420
Appellants contend that they pled that Bunting owed them a fiduciary duty separate and apart from that owed as an officer of Spartan, based upon an alleged special relationship.Â  Thus, the first question we address is whether they have pled facts sufficient to give rise to a separate duty.Â  See, e.g. Huggins v. Citibank, N.A., 355 S.C. 329, 585 S.E.2d 275 (2003) (existence of duty is question of law for the court).Â  We find no such duty was pled.
A. Basis of Duty
 Appellants concede that their special relationship was predicated in part on Buntingâ€™s status as an officer, but allege that other facts gave rise to a special relationship and consequent duty.Â  First, they alleged that Bunting was a fellow shareholder and therefore owed them a fiduciary duty by virtue of that relationship.Â  Our decisions imposing a fiduciary duty on fellow shareholders are limited to situations that involve oppression of a minority shareholder by a controlling shareholder.Â  See e.g., Lesesne v. Lesesne, 307 S.C. 67, 413 S.E.2d 847 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  There is no contention that Bunting was a controlling shareholder, or that he used fraud or oppression to procure the appellantsâ€™ shares for himself.Â  There is no breach of shareholder fiduciary duty alleged here.
Second, appellants would impose a special relationship and a fiduciary duty upon Bunting as a result of their decision to repose trust in him, and on their repeated questioning of him.Â  We decline to impose a fiduciary duty as a consequence of such unilateral actions.Â  Compare Jacobsen v. Yaschik, 249 S.C. 577, 155 S.E.2d 601 (1967) (officer owes fiduciary duty of full disclosure when purchasing shares from shareholders); Manning v. Dial, 271 S.C. 79, 245 S.E.2d 120 (1975) (same).
There are no allegations that Bunting undertook to advise the appellants.Â  Instead, appellants sought information from Bunting, based on their belief that he had special knowledge, in order to make their own informed financial decisions.Â  If Bunting had misrepresented the facts to any shareholder who had inquired, then he would have breached the identical fiduciary duty to that individual that appellants contend was owed specially to them.Â  The only breach of fiduciary duty pled here was that owed by Bunting as a corporate officer.
Finally, while appellants repeatedly argue they are not basing the claim that Bunting owed them a duty solely on the basis of his status as an officer of Spartan, this contention is belied by their pleadings.
In the first cause of action for Breach of Fiduciary Duty, the appellants allege:

  39.Â  Spartan and Mr. Bunting were fiduciaries with regard to the shareholders of Spartan, [appellants] placed special trust and confidence in Spartan and Mr. Bunting; and Spartan and Mr. Bunting owed [appellants] a fiduciary duty.
  â€¦
  43.Â  In addition to its direct liability to [appellants] Spartan is vicariously liable for the conduct of Mr. Buntingâ€¦.
  44.Â  Mr. Bunting and [Spartanâ€™s successor] are liable to [appellants]â€¦.

 The second cause of action, titled Negligent Misrepresentation, alleges the following:

  46.Â  Spartan and Mr. Bunting owed [appellants] a duty of due careâ€¦
  47.Â  Spartan and Mr. Bunting were negligent, grossly negligent, reckless, willful, and wanton in their communicationsâ€¦
  48.Â  In addition to its direct liability to [appellants], Spartan is vicariously liable for the conduct of Mr. Bunting.

The fourth cause of action, entitled Breach of Fiduciary Duty-Unjust Enrichment alleges:

  56.Â  Spartan and Mr. Bunting were fiduciaries with regard to the shareholders of Spartan; [appellants] placed a special confidence in Spartan and Mr. Bunting; and Spartan and Mr. Bunting owed [appellants] a fiduciary duty;
  â€¦
  59.Â  Spartan and Mr. Bunting breached their fiduciary duty to all Spartan shareholders when they approved these windfall [stock] options, which caused additional damages to the [appellants] in that the issue of these options diluted the total consideration from the sale of Spartan that should have been divided pro rata among all of the shareholders.
  â€¦
  61.Â  [Spartanâ€™s successor] is liable to the [appellants] for the pro rata share they would have received based on the fair market value of Spartanâ€™s stock before the windfall options diluted the companyâ€™s value.

The pleadings conclusively demonstrate that appellants pled a breach of the fiduciary duty owed by Bunting as a corporate officer.Â  The next question of law we address is whether an action for breach of that duty must be brought pursuant to the statute, or whether a common law duty continues to exist. 
B. Source of Duty
That the General Assembly intended the South Carolina Business Corporation Act (Act) to codify[2] the common law duties owed to shareholders by officers and directors is made clear by the South Carolina Reportersâ€™ Comments (Reportersâ€™ Comments).Â  Section 33-8-420, at issue here, sets forth the standards for corporate officers, while S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-8-300 (1990) covers the standards for corporate directors.Â  The Reportersâ€™ Comments to the officersâ€™ statute state, â€œThis section basically applies the standards of Section 33-8-300 to officers.Â  The [Reportersâ€™ Comments] to Section 33-8-300 apply.â€Â  We therefore look to those directorsâ€™ comments in aid of determining the legislatureâ€™s intent with regard to fiduciary duties.
The Reportersâ€™ Comments to Â§ 33-8-300 contain the following:

  As the foregoing authorities suggest, the underlying principle of shareholders being express beneficiaries of fiduciary duties predates the technical amendment made in 1963.Â  South Carolina case law since Black v. Simpson, 94 S.C. 312, 77 S.E. 1023 (1913), has firmly embraced the notion that officers and directors owe duties to shareholders as well as the entity.Â  The principle has been applied in insider trading cases (see Jacobson v. Yaschik, 249 S.C. 577, 584, 155 S.E.2d 601, 605 (1967)) and squeeze-out cases (see Dibble v. Sumter Ice & Fuel Co., 283 S.C. 278, 322 S.E.2d 674 (1984)).
  In 1981, the Model Actâ€™s articulation of duties owed was adopted verbatim with the exception that the established principle that shareholders of South Carolina corporations are express statutory beneficiaries of duties owed was retained.Â  
  â€¦.
  Basically, the drafters of the current [1988] revision faced three alternatives: follow the [1984] Model Act entirely; continue the pattern of following the Model Act but with added express recognition of the legal principle that duties run to shareholders; or opt for a very pro-insider statute along the lines recently adopted by Delaware.
  â€¦.
  The decision of whether to adhere strictly to the Model Act, to maintain the status quo in this State, or to opt for the Delaware approach (or one even more liberal) raised philosophical pointsâ€¦.Â  One concern of proponents of the status quo is that dropping from the statute a duty that previously existed can hardly be taken as anything different than a repudiation of prior law.
  â€¦.
  After detailed discussion and analysis, the decision was made to retain mention in this provision of a direct duty owed to shareholders.
  â€¦.

The common law fiduciary duty, first recognized in 1913, owed to shareholders by corporate officers and directors has been codified by Â§Â§ 33-8-300 and -420.Â  The trial court correctly held that appellantsâ€™ breach of fiduciary duty claims against Bunting must be brought within the statuteâ€™s terms.
III. Statute of Limitations
We have determined that appellantsâ€™ claims predicated on a breach of fiduciary duty must be brought pursuant to the statute.Â  Appellants alleged three theories:Â  Breach of Fiduciary Duty, Negligent Misrepresentation, and Breach of Fiduciary Duty-Unjust Enrichment.Â  The trial court held that since there was only one wrong alleged, that is, Buntingâ€™s misrepresentation that no merger was planned, all three theories should be treated as a single breach of fiduciary duty claim.Â  As we read the complaint, however, appellants alleged two separate wrongs: the Breach of Fiduciary Duty and Negligent Misrepresentation claims involve Buntingâ€™s responses to appellantsâ€™ inquiries, while the Breach of Fiduciary Duty-Unjust Enrichment claim alleged Spartan and Bunting breached a fiduciary duty owed to all stockholders when â€œtheyâ€[3] approved windfall stock options prior to the sale to Media General, thereby diluting the sale proceeds that should have been divided pro rata among all shareholders.Â  We will discuss this Unjust Enrichment wrong first.
A. Unjust Enrichment
Appellants allege corporate malfeasance that resulted in identical harm to all shareholders: such a breach of fiduciary duty gives rise to a classic shareholdersâ€™ derivative suit.Â  See Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 557 S.E.2d 676 (Ct. App. 2001) (diminution in value of stock suffered by all shareholders must be brought as a derivative action); 12B Fletcher Cyclopedia Corporations Â§ 5909 (2000).Â  A derivative action that does not meet the pleading requirements of Rule 23(b)(1), SCRCP, is properly dismissed pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6). Â Carolina First Corp. v. Whittle, 343 S.C. 176, 539 S.E.2d 402 (Ct. App. 2000).
We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of the Unjust Enrichment cause of action under Rule 12(b)(6).Â  Brown v. Stewart; Carolina First; Rule 220(c), SCACR (court may affirm for any reason appearing in the record).
B. Breach of Fiduciary Duty/Negligent Misrepresentation
The remaining two causes of action allege a breach of fiduciary duty.[4]Â  The trial court held these claims were barred by the statute of limitations in Â§ 33-8-420(e), as they were admittedly brought more than two years after appellants discovered the alleged breach.Â  Appellants contend the circuit court misconstrued the statute.Â  We affirm.
Section 33-8-420(e) provides:

  An action against an officer for failure to perform the duties imposed by this section must be commenced within three years after the cause of action has accrued, or within two years after the time when the cause of action is discovered, or should reasonably have been discovered, whichever sooner occurs.Â  This limitations period does not apply to breaches of duty which have been concealed fraudulently.

The circuit court held the last sentence of this section should be read to apply only to that part of the statute placing a three year accrual limit on an action.Â  In other words, a plaintiff must bring an action within two years of discovery or within three years of the accrual, except that when the breach has been fraudulently concealed, the three year outer limit does not apply, and the two-year discovery rule governs.Â  This reading is supported by the Reportersâ€™ Comments to Â§ 33-8-300(e), the statute of limitations for directorsâ€™ suits that contains identical language.
 The Reportersâ€™ Comments state:

  The third difference between prior law and the Model Act section is that the South Carolina statute, since the enactment of the 1981 South Carolina Business Corporation Act, has had a special statute of limitations found in Section 33-13-150(d).Â  As enacted it cut off suits based on violations of the statute unless brought:
  â€œwithin three (3) years after the cause of action has accrued, or within two years after the time when the cause of action is discovered, or should reasonably have been discovered, whichever sooner occurs.â€
  Note that under the statute, the plaintiffâ€™s right to bring a cause of action which had been concealed, and could never have been reasonably discovered, lapsed after three years.Â  There was no provision for tolling based on fraudulent concealment.Â  Arguably, the statute would reward fraudulent concealment of a wrong.Â  The statute was flawed.Â  If the statute rewarded fraudulent concealment by corporate fiduciaries, it was bad policy; if it was intended not to apply in cases of fraudulent concealment, it was poorly drafted.
  The leading proponents of adding the statute of limitations to the Model Act section were also the leading proponents for elimination of the duty to shareholders on the theory that it was better to have the Model Act unsullied by local law.
  There was a general willingness to import a specific limitations period into the statute defining duties owed.Â  This was accomplished by adding to the Model Act provision a new subsection (e) which reads the same as Section 33-13-150(d) of prior law, but with this limitation added at the end: â€œThis limitations period does not apply to breaches of duty which have been concealed fraudulently.â€Â  The advantage to the short limitations period set forth in subsection (e) is not available to fiduciaries who fraudulently conceal their wrongdoing.

A breach of fiduciary duty suit against a corporate officer or director, even where that breach has been concealed, must be brought no later than two years after discovery of that breach.Â  Here, the suit was admittedly commenced more than two years after discovery.Â  The circuit court properly dismissed the Breach of Fiduciary Duty and Negligent Misrepresentation claims under Rule 12(b)(6) as they were brought after the expiration of the statute of limitations. [5] Carolina Care Plan, Inc., supra. 
CONCLUSION
The circuit court order dismissing the appellantsâ€™ complaint pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, is 
AFFIRMED.
BURNETT, J., and Acting Justice J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., concur.Â  MOORE, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J., concurs.
JUSTICE MOORE:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  Unlike the majority, I would hold the amendment to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-510 (Supp. 2004) gives rise to a private cause of action under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-1210 (Supp. 2004) and does not limit private causes of action to instances where a surety bond has been posted.Â  
Additionally, I would find that the common law causes of action alleged were not abrogated by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-8-420 (1990).Â  Simply because the General Assembly enacted a statute addressing the fiduciary duty owed to shareholders by corporate officers or directors does not mean that it intended to abrogate all common law causes of action involving corporate officers or directors and shareholders.Â  See State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 66, 447 S.E.2d 177, 182 (1993) (â€œCommon law offenses are not abrogated simply because there is a statutory offense proscribing similar conduct. Rather, it is presumed that no change in common law is intended unless the Legislature explicitly indicates such an intention by language in the statute.â€) (citations omitted).Â  See also Nuckolls v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co., 192 S.C. 156, 161, 5 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1939) (â€œ[I]t is not presumed that the Legislature intended to abrogate or modify a rule of the common-law by the enactment of a statute upon the same subject; that it is rather to be presumed that no change in the common-law was intended unless the language employed clearly indicates such an intention . . . .â€).Â  There is nothing in the Reporterâ€™s Comments cited by the majority or the statute itself that indicates the General Assembly intended to abrogate all common law causes of action involving corporate directors and officers and shareholders.Â  
Furthermore, even if Â§ 33-8-420 applies, I would find the statute of limitations period set forth in subsection (e) does not bar appellantsâ€™ claims. Section 33-80-420(e) provides:Â  

  An action against an officer for failure to perform the duties imposed by this section must be commenced within three years after the cause of action has accrued, or within two years after the time when the cause of action is discovered, or should reasonably have been discovered, whichever sooner occurs. This limitations period does not apply to breaches of duty which have been concealed fraudulently.

(Emphasis added).Â  The majority states that the Reporterâ€™s Comments to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-8-300 (1990) support its conclusion that the last sentence in Â§ 33-8-420(e) applies only to the three-year statute of limitations period.Â  I disagree.Â  This subsection sets forth only one period, whichever occurs sooner of three years from the actual accrual or two years from discovery, and â€œthis limitations periodâ€ does not apply when fraudulent concealment is alleged.Â  The Reporterâ€™s Comments specifically state:Â  â€œThe advantage of the short limitations period set forth in subsection (e) is not available to fiduciaries who fraudulently conceal their wrongdoing.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  In my opinion, the last sentence in this subsection does not apply only to the three-year period and I would find this entire subsection inapplicable.Â  I would hold that appellants had three years from discovery, pursuant to the general statute of limitations set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (2005), in which to bring their claims.Â  
Accordingly, I would reverse the order dismissing appellantsâ€™ complaint.
TOAL, C.J., concurs.

[1] We need not decide whether Bunting is a registered broker-dealer, agent, or investment advisor within the meaning of this statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-20 (Supp. 2004) (definitions under Uniform Securities Act).
[2] The dissent would find that the Act does not abrogate the common law duties.Â  We agree that those duties have not been abrogated, that is, â€œannulled, cancelled, repealed or destroyedâ€ as that term is defined in Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, but rather hold that the duties have been codified, as is the Legislatureâ€™s prerogative.Â  See, e.g. Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 562, 615 S.E.2d 98 (2005) (statute codifies common law rule that alimony terminates at death).
[3] We strongly suspect that the board of directors, rather than an officer and the corporate entity, committed the alleged misdeed.Â  Since we are reviewing the grant of a Rule 12 (b) (6) motion to dismiss, we must accept the complaintâ€™s allegations as true.
[4] As we recently clarified, a breach of fiduciary duty is an action at law.Â  See Jordan v. Holt, ___ S.C. ___, 608 S.E.2d 129 (2005).
[5] The dissent begins its analysis of the statute of limitations issue by assuming that Â§ 33-8-420 applies, but concludes by holding that this section is â€œinapplicableâ€ and that the appellants had three years to bring their claim pursuant to the general statute, Â§ 15-3-530.Â  We adhere to our analysis of Â§ 33-8-420, which is borne out by the Reportersâ€™ Comments.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Richland County Magistrate Golie S. Augustus, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26109Â  
Submitted January 4, 2006 - Filed February 6, 2006

SUSPENDED


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        I.S. Leevy Johnson, of Columbia, for respondent.Â Â Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a sanction pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a one year suspension.Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
The South Carolina Summary Court Judgesâ€™ Association sponsored a seminar for all South Carolina summary court judges from Thursday, March 3, 2005, through Saturday, March 5, 2005, in Myrtle Beach.Â  Respondent needed the continuing legal education (CLE) hours afforded by attendance at the seminar in order to meet his mandatory CLE requirements for the reporting period of July 1, 2004 to June 30, 2005.Â  
 As instructed by respondent, an employee of respondent enrolled respondent in the seminar and picked up respondentâ€™s enrollment package at the seminar on Thursday, March 3rd.Â  Based on his enrollment in his seminar, the South Carolina Supreme Court Commission on CLE & Specialization (the CLE Commission) sent respondent a Form K/Report (Compliance Report) which included twelve hours of CLE credit for attendance at all three days of the seminar.Â  
Respondent signed the Compliance Report under oath before a notary public and then submitted the signed and notarized report to the CLE Commission.Â  In actuality, respondent did not attend the first two days of the seminar and only attended the seminar on the third day (which was scheduled from 10:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m., including a 1Â½ hour non-credit adjournment for lunch).Â  
On or about October 26, 2005, Disciplinary Counsel filed a complaint with the Commission alleging respondent did not attend the seminar on Thursday, March 3rd or Friday, March 4th.Â  Respondent was required to file a written response to the complaint.Â  In his October 27, 2005 written response, respondent asserted he attended the seminar on Friday, March 4th from 9:00 a.m. through 5:00 p.m., as well as Saturday, March 5th from 10:30 a.m. through 3:00 p.m.Â  
Disciplinary Counsel initiated an investigation and requested Special Investigator James L. Evans, Jr., of the Attorney Generalâ€™s Office interview respondent.Â  Investigator Evans interviewed respondent over the telephone on October 31 and November 1, 2005.Â  In both interviews, respondent admitted he did not attend the seminar on Thursday, March 3rd, and asserted he had attended the seminar on Friday, March 4th, and Saturday, March 5th.Â  Â Â 
When respondent signed the initial Compliance Report, made his initial written response to Disciplinary Counsel, and gave oral statements to Investigator Evans, respondent knew or should have known he had not attended the seminar on Friday, March 4th, and knew or should have known that his representations to the contrary were false.Â  Also, when respondent filed the initial Compliance Report, he knew or should have known that he had not attended the seminar on Thursday, March 3rd, contrary to the information he certified in the report.Â  
On November 3, 2005, respondent sent correspondence to Disciplinary Counsel in which he acknowledged he only attended the Saturday, March 5th portion of the seminar.Â  Subsequently, respondent amended the Compliance Report, changing his CLE hours earned for the seminar from twelve hours to four hours, thereby claiming CLE credit for only Saturday, March 5th.Â  Respondent filed the amended Compliance Report with the CLE Commission.Â  Respondent amended the Compliance Report by making a pen and ink change to the CLE hours and without having the amended Compliance Report re-notarized or the change initialed by the notary.Â  On November 29, 2005, respondent filed an amended response with Disciplinary Counsel.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent admits he has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining and enforcing high standards of conduct, and shall personally observe those standards so that the integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); and Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary).Â  Respondent admits that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate Judgeâ€™s Oath of Office) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  
CONCLUSION 
We find respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a suspension from judicial duties.Â  We therefore accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent for one (1) year.Â  
SUSPENDED.
MOORE, A.C.J., BURNETT and PLEICONES, J.J., concur. TOAL, C.J., not participating; WALLER, J., not participating.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Marlene T. Sipes, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26110
Submitted December 28, 2005 - Filed February 6, 2006

DISBARRED


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Charles N. Pearman, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Marlene T. Sipes, pro se, of Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any sanction pursuant to Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR. The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Matter I
Respondent represented Complainant Aâ€™s ex-wife in divorce proceedings between Complainant A and his ex-wife.Â  As part of the divorce settlement between Complainant A and his ex-wife, Complainant A agreed to pay $22,000 to his ex-wife to extinguish a portion of the partiesâ€™ $40,000 marital debt with the understanding that his ex-wife would pay off the entire marital debt using Complainant Aâ€™s $22,000 and her own funds for the balance.Â  
In December 2003, respondent received the $22,000 from Complainant A and placed those funds in her trust account.Â  The balance in the trust account prior to the deposit of the $22,000 was $0.Â  Â Respondent then transferred $2,200 from her trust account to her personal account which, according to notations on respondentâ€™s bank statement, represented a â€œ10% debt settlement fee.â€Â  Neither Complainant A nor his ex-wife agreed to, were advised about, or were even aware of the â€œ10% debt settlement fee.â€ 
From December 2003 through April 2004, respondent transferred client funds totaling $14,600 from her trust account to her personal account.Â  The $14,600 was not used to pay the marital debts of Complainant A and his ex-wife or for any other benefit to Complainant A and his ex-wife.Â  The funds were used for respondentâ€™s own personal benefit.[1]Â  Respondent diverted a total of $19,311.67 in funds belonging to Complainant A and his ex-wife from her trust account to her own personal use without knowledge or acquiescence of Complainant A and his ex-wife. Â 
From January 2004 through April 2004, respondent made two deposits of personal funds totaling $7,900 into her trust account. Â From December 2003 through April 2004, respondent made payments to Complainant A and his ex-wifeâ€™s creditors totaling $8,475.26 using funds paid into the trust account by respondent.Â  
Impermissible interest earned on the trust account funds was credited to respondent by the bank on a monthly basis.Â  The interest was retained by respondent and not remitted to the South Carolina Bar in accordance with Rule 412, SCACR.Â  
At the end of April 2004, the balance in respondentâ€™s trust account was $17.59 when the amount of client funds belonging to Complainant A and his ex-wife should have been $13,524.75.Â  Respondent acknowledges she did not have this amount in cash or on deposit in any bank account at the end of April 2004.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
From May 2004 through the present, respondent has made additional payments of $5,096.32 to Complainant A and his ex-wifeâ€™s creditors.Â  The total amount paid by respondent to date on behalf of Complainant A and his ex-wife is $13,571.58.Â  Respondent does not have the balance of Complainant A and his ex-wifeâ€™s funds of $8,428.42 in her trust account or elsewhere and, in fact, her trust account has reached a $0 balance and has been closed by the bank.Â  As a result of respondentâ€™s actions and inactions, Complainant A and his ex-wifeâ€™s credit ratings have been severely impaired and the majority of their $40,000 marital debt remains outstanding.Â  
In May 2005, ODC issued a subpoena to respondent requiring the production of certain bank records including reconciliations, check stubs, deposit slips, and trust account ledgers.Â  Respondent produced some of the requested information but could not locate, and therefore, could not provide, much of the information, notwithstanding the maintenance of documentation required by Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent has completely failed to reconcile her trust account has failed to comply with other requirements of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
Matter II
Respondent represented Complainant B in a divorce action.Â  Over the course of the representation, Complainant B repeatedly attempted to contact respondent via telephone, e-mail, and through third parties.Â  Respondent frequently failed to respond to Complainant Bâ€™s communications, thereby failing to properly and reasonably communicate with Complainant B regarding the status of her case.Â  

In 1989, respondent was suspended from the practice of law for one year.Â  In the Matter of Sipes, 297 S.C. 531, 377 S.E.2d 574 (1989).Â  In 2003, respondent received a letter of caution with a finding of minor misconduct citing Rule 1.16 of Rule 407, SCACR.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by her misconduct, she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep a client reasonably informed about the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.5 (lawyerâ€™s fee shall be reasonable); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of clients in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection with a representation separate from the lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving moral turpitude); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  Respondent further admits her misconduct violated Rule 417, SCACR.Â  She agrees her misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  
In addition, within thirty (30) days of the date of this order, ODC and respondent shall file a restitution plan with the Court.Â  In the plan, respondent shall agree to pay restitution to all presently known and/or subsequently identified clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of her misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Moreover, in the restitution plan, respondent shall agree to reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection for any claims paid as a result of her misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, J.J., concur. WALLER, J., not participating.

In the Matter of Marlene T. Sipes, Respondent.

ORDER

By opinion dated February 6, 2006, respondent was disbarred from the practice of law.Â  See In the Matter of Sipes, Op. No. 26110 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed February 6, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 92).Â  The Court hereby appoints an attorney to protect respondentâ€™s clientsâ€™ interests pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
IT IS ORDERED that Zoe Sanders Nettles, Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for respondentâ€™s client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain.Â  Ms. Nettles shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to protect the interests of respondentâ€™s clients.Â  Ms. Nettles may make disbursements from respondentâ€™s trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain that are necessary to effectuate this appointment.
This Order, when served on any bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or operating accounts of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent respondent from making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve as notice to the bank or other financial institution that Zoe Sanders Nettles, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court.
Finally, this Order, when served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve as notice that Zoe Sanders Nettles, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court and has the authority to receive respondent's mail and the authority to direct that respondentâ€™s mail be delivered to Ms. Nettlesâ€™ office.
This appointment shall be for a period of no longer than nine months unless request is made to this Court for an extension.Â Â Â  

  
     
    s/James E. Moore                             _J.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Donald A. Kennedy, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26111
Submitted December 22, 2005 - Filed February 6, 2006Â  

DISBARRED


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Susan M. Johnston, Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to disbarment pursuant to Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In addition, respondent agrees to pay restitution to clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of his misconduct.Â  We accept the agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â 

FACTS
Matter I
Respondent had previously represented Complainant A in a quiet title action involving real property.Â  Thereafter, Complainant A became involved in or was threatened with litigation involving easements related to the real property that was the subject of the previous quiet title action.Â  With respondentâ€™s acquiescence, Complainant A delivered his file related to the easement issue to respondentâ€™s office for review.Â  Approximately two (2) months went by without Complainant A hearing from respondent on this matter.Â Â Â Â  
Complainant A tried without success to contact respondent about the matter and then launched an intensive campaign to contact respondent at his office.Â  Complainant A also wrote respondent several â€œheatedâ€ letters which respondent found offensive.Â  Thereafter, respondent left a voice message on Complainant Aâ€™s home answering machine which contained abusive and profane language about the matter.Â  Complainant A stated that this message was heard by his wife and children.Â  
When Complainant A went to retrieve his file from respondent, respondent made a remark which Complainant A interpreted as respondent was going to â€œcreate a problem for [Complainant A]â€ or words of similar import and effect.Â  
Respondent never agreed to undertake the easement matter other than to review the file on the issue.Â  After reviewing the file, considering his relationship with Complainant A, and considering his other workload, respondent decided he did not want to undertake to represent Complainant A in the easement matter and so advised him.Â  Respondent now recognizes he should not have used abusive or profane language in dealing with Complainant A, that he should have been more prompt in deciding whether or not to undertake representation in the easement matter, that his communications with Complainant A about whether or not he would undertake the matter were not as they should have been, and that the file should have been returned to Complainant A if respondent was not going to undertake representation of Complainant A in the new matter.Â  Â 
Matter II
Complainant B transmitted money to respondent to fund two real estate transactions.Â  The first transaction was closed with a profit to Complainant B.Â  As a result, there should have been approximately $7,000 in one of respondentâ€™s trust accounts to be applied toward the closing of the second transaction.Â  In contemplation of closing the second transaction, Complainant B also transmitted additional money to respondent which should have left a balance in respondentâ€™s trust account in excess of $20,000 belonging to Complainant B.
Complainant B was later advised by a non-attorney employee on respondentâ€™s staff that the second transaction had not been closed, that the file had been turned over to another attorney, and that there were insufficient funds in respondentâ€™s trust account to refund the money to Complainant B.Â  The title insurance company involved in this transaction made a partial refund to Complainant B, but denied liability for the balance inasmuch as respondent had not caused an insured closing letter to be issued in connection with the transaction.Â  As a result, Complainant B suffered a loss of approximately $18,000.Â  Respondent acknowledges that the cause of this loss was the fact that he misappropriated all or at least a substantial portion of the funds and/or applied them toward purposes other than intended without the consent or knowledge of Complainant B.Â Â Â  
Matter III
Respondent served as a qualified tax intermediary in a Section 1031 Tax Deferred Exchange in connection with a real estate transaction where Complainant C was the initial seller and sought to locate replacement property for a like-kind exchange.Â  As a result, approximately $40,000 was turned over to respondent.Â  This money was deposited into one of respondentâ€™s trust accounts and was supposed to be held by respondent to be expended in connection with that transaction upon direction of the beneficiary for which the funds were being held.Â  Thereafter, respondent misappropriated those funds in their entirety or used the entire amount of those funds for purposes other than intended without the knowledge or consent of Complainant C.Â  
Complainant C made a claim to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection (Lawyersâ€™ Fund).Â  The Lawyersâ€™ Fund approved a payment to Complainant C in the amount of $20,000 (the maximum payment that could be made under the applicable rules to a single complainant) leaving Complainant C with a financial loss as a result of respondentâ€™s misconduct. 
Matter IV
Complainant D is an attorney who specialized in tax matters.Â  Complainant D and respondent were, for a period of time, law partners operating under as a limited liability company (LLC).Â  This LLC was for the limited purpose of handling Section 1031 tax deferred real estate exchanges.Â  Otherwise, respondent and Complainant D maintained separate law practices. Â Complainant D terminated his relationship with respondent after he determined respondent had engaged in professional misconduct on several occasions and in the several matters set forth below. 
A.
Respondent decided to refinance his personal residence with a bank loan.Â  Respondent requested Complainant D conduct the title search, review the closing documents, and serve as the settlement agent, including executing the HUD-1 Settlement Statement as closing attorney/settlement agent in connection with the refinancing.Â  Complainant D was scheduled to be out of state on the day of the closing of the refinancing transaction.Â  For that reason, Complainant D and respondent agreed that the loan proceeds would be deposited into one of respondentâ€™s trust accounts and disbursed by respondent.Â Â  
The original HUD-1 Settlement Statement signed by Complainant D showed payoffs to several other lenders who had prior liens on the property and showed very little or no â€œcash to borrower.â€Â  Complainant D signed page two of the HUD-1 Settlement Statement as â€œsettlement agent.â€Â  Thereafter, respondent drafted or caused to be drafted a new page one of the HUD-1 Settlement Statement.Â  This new HUD-1 provided a disbursement to respondent (i.e., â€œcash to borrowerâ€) of approximately $157,266 and omitted the payoffs to the other lenders that were supposed to be paid according to the original HUD-1 signed by Complainant D.Â  Complainant D had not authorized and did not know about the new page one until after the closing and disbursements in connection with the transaction.Â  
Respondent received loan proceeds from the lender in the amount of $280,000 in connection with the refinancing transaction.Â  He did not pay off the holders of the prior liens and, instead, converted and used approximately $157,266 for purposes other than intended by or known to the lender.Â  As a result, these prior liens remained senior in priority to the lien of the refinancing lender.Â  Â Â Â 
 In connection with the refinancing transaction, respondent asked Complainant D to execute the loan policy of title insurance on behalf of the title insurance company as his â€œlicensee.â€ Â Respondent assured Complainant D that he could, under respondentâ€™s agency agreement with the title insurance company, authorize Complainant D to sign the title insurance policy on behalf of the title company as â€œlicenseeâ€ of respondent.[1]Â  In reliance on respondentâ€™s assurance, Complainant D signed his own name to the loan title insurance policy on behalf of the title insurance company.Â  
Respondent presented the title policy to the lender.Â  The lender questioned certain aspects of the loan policy presented and required that an amended loan policy be issued containing certain additional requirements of the lender.Â  Respondent then redrafted the loan policy, signed or allowed someone else to sign Complainant Dâ€™s name to the loan policy on behalf of the title insurance company, and then presented this new loan policy to the lender bearing Complainant Dâ€™s forged signature.Â  In reliance on the provisions of this new loan policy, the lender tendered the loan proceeds to respondent.Â  
The amended loan policy of title insurance reflects that the refinancing lender had a first mortgage lien on the subject property when, in fact, there were several prior and, therefore, superior liens on the subject property (respondentâ€™s residence) which was well known to respondent.Â  The lender consummated the refinanced loan transaction in reliance on the information in the amended loan policy of title insurance which falsely certified that the refinancing lender had a first lien on the subject property.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
B.
In another matter, respondent represented a client in connection with a Section 1031 exchange.Â  While Complainant D was out of the state, the LLC received a $943,265.08 check in connection with this 1031 exchange.Â  Respondent or someone acting on his behalf or under or subject to his direction and/or supervision endorsed this check â€œPay to [Respondentâ€™s] Law Officeâ€ (not the LLC partnership).Â  This check was then deposited into one of respondentâ€™s trust accounts.Â  Respondent then prepared or caused to be prepared a check on that trust account transferring $943,265.08 into another trust account maintained by respondent at another bank.Â  
Respondent ultimately disbursed funds on the 1031 tax deferred exchange, but one check issued in the amount of $77,543.52 by respondent on one of his trust accounts in connection with the exchange was not honored upon presentment due to insufficient funds in the trust account.Â  Respondent admits the check was not honored because he had misappropriated these funds and/or converted the funds for purposes other than intended.Â  The client made a claim for these funds with the title insurance company which made a payment to the client in the amount of $79,787.79.Â  
Matter V
On August 26, 2002, respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Kennedy, ___ S.C. ___, 623 S.E.2d 640 (2002). Â Respondent acknowledges that, at that time, he had shortages in his trust account of approximately $280,000. Â Respondent further acknowledges that, immediately prior to his interim suspension, he had approximately thirteen bank accounts and that he failed to follow the recordkeeping and money handling requirements of Rule 417, SCACR, in connection with the various trust accounts.Â  From time to time, respondent used money in his trust accounts which belonged to his clients to pay his personal expenses.Â  
Respondent has represented to ODC that the cause of the acknowledged shortage in his trust accounts was the failure of a lender to wire loan proceeds into one of the trust accounts approximately twelve years ago.Â  Respondent stated he incorrectly believed the funds had been wired into the trust account and closed a transaction and disbursed the proceeds reflected in that transaction when he had not actually received the proceeds.Â  However, respondent can neither Â remember nor identify the name of the lender who failed to wire those loan proceeds to his trust account and he cannot identify the client in that transaction. 
ODC has determined and contends that the total shortage in respondentâ€™s trust account in fact grew to the approximate sum of $420,000 at the time respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â Â For purposes of this agreement, respondent does not contest that contention.Â  However, respondent has represented to ODC that he suspects someone on his staff embezzled some money out of the trust account, thereby causing the known shortage of approximately $280,000 to increase to the actual amount thereof.Â  Respondent has not been able to provide records to support his suspicion.Â  
As a result of the shortage in his various trust accounts (whether the sum of $280,000 as acknowledged by respondent or the approximate sum of $420,000 as contended by ODC), respondentÂ  instituted a scheme of check kiting and/or moving money between his various bank accounts to cover the shortages.Â  On at least one occasion, a bank required respondent to cover shortages in his personal account.Â  Respondent paid the bank with numerous checks written on one or more of his law firmâ€™s trust accounts to cover the shortages.Â  
The Lawyersâ€™ Fund has paid $68,596 in claims made against respondent as a result of his misconduct.Â  The title insurance company mentioned herein reports that, as of August 19, 2004, it has paid damages in the amount of $836,421 as a result of claims made in connection with the foregoing activities of respondent.Â  For purposes of this agreement, respondent does not dispute the title insurance companyâ€™s claim.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Matter VI
On or about March 10, 2005, respondent entered a plea of guilty to one count of mail fraud in violation of 18 U.S.C. Â§ 1341 in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina.


Respondent has cooperated with ODCâ€™s investigation into these matters, including submitting to voluntary interviews, joining into a consent order releasing records to auditors, and consenting to being placed on interim suspension.Â  Until this matter, respondent had never been found to have committed professional misconduct in South Carolina.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep a client reasonably informed about the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of clients in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection with a representation separate from the lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 4.1 (in the course of representing a client, a lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of material fact to a third person); Rule 5.3 (partner in a law firm shall make reasonable efforts to ensure that the firm has in effect measures giving reasonable assurance that a non-lawyer employeeâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional obligations of the lawyer); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving moral turpitude); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  
Respondent further admits his misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 7(a)(5) ( it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute administration of justice, bring courts or legal profession into disrepute, or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law), Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate oath of office), and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to willfully violate a court order).Â  In addition, respondent admits his misconduct violated Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  The disbarment shall be retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  
In addition, within thirty (30) days of the date of this order, ODC and respondent shall file a restitution plan with the Court.Â  In the plan, respondent shall agree to pay restitution to all presently known and/or subsequently identified clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of his misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Moreover, in the restitution plan, respondent shall agree to reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for any claims paid as a result of his misconduct in connection with this matter. Â 
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, J.J., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Walter Ray Stone, Deceased, and Bonnie L. Stone, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Roadway Express, Employer, and Old Republic Insurance Company, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26113
Heard December 1, 2005 - Filed February 13, 2006Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Duke K. McCall, Jr., of Leatherwood, Walker, Todd & Mann, of Greenville, for Appellants.
        Linda Byars McKenzie, of Brown, McKenzie & Bowen, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  The issue in this case is whether the employeeâ€™s (Stoneâ€™s) widow (respondent) is entitled to continue receiving workersâ€™ compensation benefits after Stoneâ€™s death due to causes unrelated to his compensable injury.Â  The full commissionâ€™s appellate panel affirmed a single commissionerâ€™s order granting respondentâ€™s request for lump sum benefits, holding that respondentâ€™s claim was not barred by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-280 (1985), and that res judicata and/or collateral estoppel operated so as to bar appellants from contesting respondentâ€™s right to receive the money.Â  The circuit court affirmed, citing Rule 59(e), SCRCP, as an additional bar.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
After Stone injured his left foot and leg and his back at work, he brought a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  Stone subsequently developed a brain tumor.Â  In October 1999, the single commissioner found Stone permanently and totally disabled and awarded him 500 weeks of compensation pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-10 (Supp. 2004).Â  In December 1999, Stone died from complications related to his brain tumor.Â  Following a January 2000 hearing, the full commissionâ€™s appellate panel issued an order confirming Stoneâ€™s entitlement to disability payments pursuant to Â§ 42-9-10.Â  The circuit court affirmed and appellants appealed to the Court of Appeals.
On appeal, appellants argued as they had before the commission and the circuit court that Stoneâ€™s disability should have been apportioned between the injury and the tumor, resulting in a lower compensation award pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-160 (1985).Â  In its first unpublished opinion, the Court of Appeals acknowledged Stoneâ€™s death, and affirmed the award.Â  The Court of Appeals construed Â§ 42-9-160, upon which appellants based their apportionment argument, to require apportionment only between two compensable injuries, and went on to state:

  For example, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-280 (1985 & Supp. 2000) indicates that apportionment is not appropriate when death results from a noncompensable cause.

Appellants filed a petition for rehearing, arguing among other things that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-280 did not apply to Stone since he had received compensation under the first paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10 and therefore â€œhis award ceases with his death and is apportionable.â€Â Â  
The Court of Appeals denied rehearing, but issued an amended unpublished opinion in January 2002.Â  In this opinion, the Court of Appeals again affirmed, but altered its reference to Â§ 42-9-280.Â  Appellantsâ€™ petition for a writ of certiorari was denied by this Court: it did not include any argument that Stoneâ€™s claim had abated by operation of Â§ 42-9-280, since that section was not at issue in this first appellate proceeding except by virtue of the Court of Appealsâ€™ use of it as a comparative.Â  In this first series of appeals, neither respondent nor Stoneâ€™s estate was ever substituted as a party following Stoneâ€™s death.Â  See Rule 226, SCACR (substitution of party upon death, etc.).
Following the denial of certiorari, respondent filed a petition with the commission seeking a dependency hearing.Â  Appellants replied by letter that no dependency hearing was necessary as further benefit payments were barred by Â§ 42-9-280.Â  Following the dependency hearing, respondent was awarded lump sum benefits by the single commissioner, an award affirmed by an appellate panel of the full commission and the circuit court.Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUES

  1)     Are appellants precluded from contesting respondentâ€™s entitlement to benefits?
  2)     If not, does Â§ 42-9-280 preclude respondentâ€™s receipt of benefits?

ANALYSIS
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Preclusion
The commission and circuit court held appellantsâ€™ defense, that Stoneâ€™s right to benefits ceased upon his death pursuant to Â§ 42-9-280 and that respondent therefore had no claim, was barred by the doctrine of res judicata and/or the doctrine of collateral estoppel.Â  Appellants contend this was error.Â  We agree.
The res judicata/collateral estoppel rulings are based upon appellantsâ€™ failure to seek dismissal of their first appeal when Stone died following the single commissionerâ€™s order awarding Stone benefits.Â  As explained infra, appellants did seek to stay the benefits proceedings before the commission while dependency was determined, but respondentâ€™s attorneyâ€™s objection to that procedure was sustained.
Res judicata requires three elements be met: 1) a final, valid judgment on the merits; 2) identity of parties; and 3) the second action must involve matters properly included in the first suit.Â  E.g. Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 602 S.E.2d 32 (2004).Â  Here, the parties are different, and the issue is not the amount of compensation due but rather whether the right to compensation survives Stoneâ€™s death.Â  Res judicata does not bar appellantsâ€™ statute-based defense to respondentâ€™s dependency claim.
Further, the doctrine of collateral estoppel does not apply.Â  â€œCollateral estoppel prevents a party from relitigating in a subsequent suit an issue actually and necessarily litigated and determined in a prior action.â€Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 585 S.E.2d 281 (2003).Â  Respondentâ€™s entitlement to benefits following Stoneâ€™s death was neither actually litigated in the first action, nor was the entitlement issue necessary to the resolution of the amount of benefits dispute.
In addition, respondent essentially contends that appellants waived their right to contest respondentâ€™s right to benefits at the January 2000 hearing.Â  The record refutes this contention.Â  At the outset of this hearing, the following took place:

  Appellantsâ€™ attorney:Â  May it please the Chairman and members of the Appellant [sic] Panel.Â  Iâ€™m in a little bit of an unusual situation in this case in that Walter Stone is now deceased as of the end of December.Â  And I would therefore move for a continuance of this Hearing until such time as a dependency or the proper dependents can be determined.Â  Because no benefits can be paid, if they are in fact payable, until the dependency of Mr. Stone [sic] has been determined.
  (emphasis supplied).
  Commissioner Lyndon:Â  If I could hear from [Mr. Stoneâ€™s attorney] on that, sir?
  Mr. Stoneâ€™s Attorney:Â  May it please the Panel.Â  Of course, that is not even an issue before this Panel today.Â  In the first place, this is an appeal from an Order.Â  The fact that the man subsequently died, you canâ€™t have a dependency hearing, what happens to have a dependency hearing [sic] if the Commission were to say well, itâ€™s not compensable.Â  And then if you affirm the case, then of course we have a dependency hearing.
  Commissioner Lyndon:Â  I understand.Â  And I see it the way---unless my colleagues want---
  Commissioner Mickle:Â  I donâ€™t think youâ€™re prejudiced by it.
  Commissioner Lyndon:Â  I donâ€™t think youâ€™re prejudiced by it.Â  So Iâ€™ll note your Motion.
  Appellantsâ€™ Attorney:Â  I will admit weâ€™re not prejudiced by it.Â  But I would offer that in the Circuit Courts if you have a party that is deceased then the proceedings are stopped and the parties are realigned until you get an Administrator or a personal representation [sic] appointed to come into Court.
  Commissioner Atkins:Â  Excuse me, Mr. Chairman, [Appellantsâ€™ Attorney], that would just hold up the benefits at a later time.Â  I mean, we can go ahead and make this decision.Â  This can be appealed wherever it needs to be appealed so that when that situation is taken care of then they would be prejudiced if theyâ€™ve had to not be able to continue or so that they could be paid at the appropriate time once all that was taken care of.

Nothing in this passage can be construed as a waiver of appellantsâ€™ right to contest respondentâ€™s claim to benefits.Â  If anything, this colloquy could be read to estop respondent from claiming any procedural bar to the litigation now, after the first appeals have been concluded, of her right to â€œbenefitsâ€¦if they are in fact payableâ€¦.â€Â  
Similarly, any contention that appellants could or should have raised the Â§ 42-9-280 issue during the first appeals are refuted by this colloquy.Â  Only issues raised and ruled upon by the commission are cognizable on appeal.Â  E.g., TNS Mills, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Rev., 331 S.C. 611, 503 S.E.2d 741 (1998) (on appeal from agency decision, circuit court can only review issues raised to and ruled upon by the commission).Â  At respondentâ€™s attorneyâ€™s insistence, the only issue before the panel in January 2000 was the amount of benefits to which Stone was entitled.Â  In light of the commissionâ€™s ruling, appellants did not, and could not, litigate the applicability of Â§ 42-9-280.
The circuit court referred to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, in its conclusion that appellants were procedurally barred from denying respondentâ€™s entitlement to Stoneâ€™s benefits.Â  Apparently, the ruling is premised on the misapprehension that once the commissionâ€™s appellate panel declined to discontinue the appeal pending a dependency hearing as appellants had requested, appellants were obligated to file a Rule 59(e) motion before the appellate panel to preserve the issue.Â  Rule 59(e) is not applicable in proceedings before the commission.Â  See Nettles v. Spartanburg School Dist. #7, 341 S.C. 580, 535 S.E.2d 146, fn. 4 (Ct. App. 2000). 
Respondent also asserts as a sustaining ground that appellantsâ€™ invocation of Â§ 42-9-280 should be barred by laches.Â  Given that when appellants raised the effect of Stoneâ€™s death at the first available opportunity, that is, the January 2000 hearing before the appellate panel, respondent objected, and that appellants raised the issue at their next opportunity, that is, in response to respondentâ€™s request for a dependency hearing, equity will not and should not aid respondent.Â  See e.g., Hemingway v. Mention, 228 S.C. 211, 89 S.E.2d 369 (1955) (laches invoked where appellants were not vigilant).Â  Laches does not bar appellantsâ€™ defense.
The circuit court erred in upholding the commissionâ€™s ruling that there was a procedural bar to litigation on the merits of respondentâ€™s claim to post-death benefits.
B.Â Section 42-9-280
Stone was awarded 500 weeks of benefits based on a finding of total disability pursuant to the first paragraph of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-10.[1]Â  The statute provides:

  Â§ 42-9-10.Â  Amount of compensation for total disability; what constitutes total disability. (Title)
  When the incapacity for work resulting from an injury is total, the employer shall pay, or cause to be paid, as provided in this chapter, to the injured employee during the total disability a weekly compensation equal to sixty-six and two-thirds percent of his average weekly wages, but not less than seventy-five dollars a week so long as this amount does not exceed his average weekly salary; if this amount does exceed his average weekly salary, the injured employee may not be paid, each week, less than his average weekly salary.Â  The injured employee may not be paid more each week than the average weekly wage in this State for the preceding fiscal year.Â  In no case may the period covered by the compensation exceed five hundred weeks except as hereinafter provided. (1st paragraph)
  The loss of both hands, arms, feet, legs, or vision in both eyes, or any two thereof, constitutes total and permanent disability to be compensated according to the provisions of this section. (2nd paragraph)
  Notwithstanding the five hundred week limitation prescribed in this section or elsewhere in this title, any person determined to be totally and permanently disabled who as a result of a compensable injury is a paraplegic, a quadriplegic, or who has suffered physical brain damage is not subject to the five hundred week limitation and shall receive the benefits for life. (3rd paragraph)
  Notwithstanding the provisions of Â§ 42-9-301, no total lump sum payment may be ordered by the commission in any case under this section where the injured person is entitled to lifetime benefits. (4th paragraph)

Appellants contend the commission and circuit court erred in concluding that the right to Stoneâ€™s benefits did not terminate upon his death pursuant to Â§ 42-9-280. Â The statute provides:

  Â§ 42-9-280.Â  Payment of unpaid balance of compensation when employee dies.
  When an employee receives or is entitled to compensation under this Title for an injury covered by the second paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10 or 42-9-30[2] and dies from any other cause than the injury for which he was entitled to compensation, payment of the unpaid balance of compensation shall be made to his next of kin dependent upon him for support, in lieu of the compensation the employee would have been entitled to had he lived.Â  But if the death is due to a cause that is compensable under this Title and the dependents of such employee are awarded compensation therefor, all right to unpaid compensation provided by this section shall cease and determine.

Appellants contend that since Stoneâ€™s benefits were based upon paragraph 1 of Â§ 42-9-10, the right to compensation abated upon his death from the brain tumor.Â  The commission based its decision to continue benefits to respondent despite Â§ 42-9-280 on this reasoning:

  It is inconceivable that the legislature intended to protect the widow and/or dependents who are dependent upon the deceased employee for support only when the deceased employee suffered a schedule loss as set forth in Â§ 42-9-10 or Â§ 42-9-30.Â  This clearly would defeat the beneficent purpose for which the workersâ€™ compensation law was passed, that being to protect the injured employee and his dependents.Â  To hold otherwise would deprive the widow in this case of the equal protection of the law.

The commission then cited Â§ 42-9-290 as evidence of â€œthe legislative intent to take care of those dependent upon an employee whose injury is work related.â€Â  As appellants correctly point out, Â§ 42-9-290 is the applicable statute where the employee dies from the injury or accident which entitled him to workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  It simply has no application to Â§ 42-9-280, which applies when, as here, the employee dies from an independent cause.
The circuit court upheld the commissionâ€™s order.Â  It began by reciting numerous cases which stand for the principle that the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act must be liberally construed in favor of injured workers and their dependents.Â  It concluded that â€œif the legislature meant to abrogate the rights of an individual such as [respondent] such would have been set forth in plain language.â€Â  
The language of Â§ 42-9-280 is plain.Â  The legislature, as is its prerogative, determined that dependent survivors should receive all benefits due an injured worker who lost the use of a scheduled member (Â§ 42-9-30), or â€œlost both hands, arms, feet, legs, or vision in both eyes, or any two thereofâ€ (second paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10), i.e., those who suffered a physical loss, while the dependents of a person totally disabled for another reason, i.e., one who suffered a wage loss compensated under the first paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10, should not.Â  The legislative distinction between â€œphysical lossâ€ and â€œwage lossâ€ appears in other workersâ€™ compensation statutes as well.Â  See e.g., Â§Â§ 42-9-150; 42-9-160; 42-9-170.
Professor Larson notes that since a compensation award, unlike a tort award, is a personal one based on the employeeâ€™s need for a substitute for lost wages and earning capacity, in the absence of a special statutory provision, heirs have no claim to unaccrued weekly payments.Â  Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law (2000) Â§Â§ 89.01; 89.03.Â  In construing a workersâ€™ compensation statute, â€œthe words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€Â  Adkins v. Comcar Industries, Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 475 S.E.2d 762 (1996) (internal citation omitted).Â  Section 42-9-280 specifically provides for the inheritability of two types of awards only.Â  We reverse the orders permitting respondent to receive unaccrued benefits.
CONCLUSION
Stone was awarded workersâ€™ compensation benefits pursuant to the first paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10.Â  Those benefits terminated upon his death from the tumor.Â  Â§ 42-9-280.Â  The circuit court order affirming the lump sum award to respondent is therefore
REVERSED.
MOORE, BURNETT, J.J., and Acting Justice D. L. Jefferson, concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

Chief Justice Toal: I respectfully dissent.Â  Appellants contested Walter Stoneâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation award for over two years after his unfortunate death, never once raising S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-280 (1985) as a bar to the recovery of benefits.Â  In my view, when a workersâ€™ compensation claimant dies while his claim is being appealed, an employer may not, after final judgment in the appeal, assert Â§ 42-9-280 in an effort to avoid paying any benefits.
Accordingly, I would affirm the circuit court and find that Respondent is entitled to receive the full amount of Walter Stoneâ€™s compensation award.


[1] Respondent argues in her brief that Stone could have been awarded benefits under Â§ 42-9-30(15) and (19) for loss of use of his back and leg.Â  Appellants conceded at oral argument that such an award could have been made, had the commission chosen to utilize that statute.Â  The order, however, unequivocally finds total disability under Â§ 42-9-10, and awards compensation pursuant to that statute alone. 
[2] This is the â€œscheduled membersâ€ statute, which was not the basis for Stoneâ€™s 500 week award.
