THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Keith Lasean Simpson, Respondent-Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Michael Moore, Commissioner, S.C. Department of Corrections, and Henry Dargan McMaster, Attorney General, 
          State of South Carolina, Petitioner-Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI 

Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26114
Submitted April 20, 2005 - Filed February 13, 2006 

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        John H. Blume, III, and Sheri L. Johnson, both of Cornell Law School, of Ithaca, NY; and Russell Ghent, of Leatherwood Walker Todd & Mann, of Greenville, for Respondent-Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia, for Petitioner-Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Respondent-Petitioner Keith Lasean Simpson (Simpson) was found guilty of murder and received a death sentence.Â  Simpson appealed and this Court affirmed.Â  State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996).Â  Simpson filed for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  The PCR court denied relief on all issues related to guilt but granted relief on sentencing.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
Simpson and his accomplice planned to rob a convenience store.Â  Armed with guns, the two men went to a store owned by Joe Harrison. Once there, Simpson went inside the store while his accomplice waited in the parking lot.Â  At the same time, a customer entered the store with his nine-year-old son, Nathan.Â  After making his purchase, the customer went outside to wait for Nathan.Â  Joe Harrison was behind the counter, working the register.
Suddenly, gunshots were fired.Â  A store employee, who was in the back of the store, testified that he saw Harrison walking towards the front door while Simpson shot at Harrison from behind. Â Nathan testified that he walked towards the front of the store to see what had happened.Â  According to Nathan, Simpson pointed the gun at Nathanâ€™s forehead and attempted to fire the gun, but it only made a clicking noise.Â  After this encounter with Simpson, Nathan ran and hid behind a poker machine.Â  Nathan testified that while he was hiding, he saw Simpson go behind the counter and take money from the cash register. Â 
Once the shooting began inside, Simpsonâ€™s accomplice shot Nathanâ€™s father, Tony Scott, outside, in the parking lot. Â Scott was injured, and Harrison, the owner, died.Â  Simpson and his accomplice fled the scene, pointing their guns and shooting at others in the area, but injuring no one else. 
Simpson was indicted for murder, armed robbery, assault and battery with intent to kill, possession of a firearm during commission of a violent crime, and five counts of pointing a firearm.Â  
At trial, Simpson gave a different version of events.Â  He testified that once inside the store, he â€œchickened out.â€Â  He claimed that he lifted his shirt, exposing the gun, as a way of signaling to his accomplice that he no longer wanted to rob the store.Â  When Simpson lifted his shirt, Harrison saw the gun, grabbed Simpson by the shirt collar, and the two began to struggle.Â  During the alleged struggle, two shots went off, Harrison began to stagger, and then Simpson fired two additional shots at Harrison.Â  In addition, Simpson testified that he did not take anything from the store when he left.
The jury found Simpson guilty of murder and he was sentenced to death.Â  He was also sentenced to serve consecutive sentences of thirty years for armed robbery, twenty years for assault, and five years for each of the pointing-a-firearm charges.Â  Simpson appealed and this Court affirmed.Â  State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996).Â  Simpson filed for post-conviction relief (PCR), and following a hearing, Simpson was denied relief on guilt but granted relief on sentencing.Â  We granted Simpsonâ€™s and the Stateâ€™s petitions for certiorari. 
Simpson raises the following issues for review:

  
    I.  
    Did the PCR court err in finding counsel was not ineffective for failing to consult an independent forensic pathologist, medical examiner, or homicide-reconstruction expert?
    
  
  
    II.     
    Did the PCR court err by denying Simpson relief due to the State’s failure to disclose potentially exculpatory evidence related to the armed-robbery charge? 
    
  
  
    III.   
    Did the PCR court err in finding the State did not engage in prosecutorial misconduct?
    
  
  
    IV.
    Did the PCR court err in finding counsel was not ineffective for failing to call an expert witness to discredit a child witness’s testimony?
    
  
  
    V.
    Did the PCR court err in finding counsel was not ineffective for failing to object to the State’s use of peremptory challenges against women?
    
  
  
    VI.
    Did the PCR court err in failing to conduct a cumulative-error analysis?
    
  

The State raises the following issues for review:

  
    I. 
    Did the PCR court err in finding Simpson was prejudiced by counsel’s failure to fully develop Simpson’s mitigation case?
    
  
  
    II.   
    Did the PCR court err by considering numerous depositions and affidavits in lieu of live testimony? 
  

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
This Court gives great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law. Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (citing McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995)).  On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any evidence of probative value sufficient to support them.  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).  If no probative evidence exists to support the findings, this Court will reverse.  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000) (citing Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996)).
To establish a claim that counsel was ineffective, a PCR applicant must show that (1) counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness and (2) but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability that the outcome of the trial would have been different. Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 688, 694 (1984); Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcomeâ€ of the trial.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694, 104 S. Ct. at 2068.
Discussion
Issues Raised by Simpson
I.Â  Failure to Consult a Forensic Expert
Simpson contends that the PCR court erred in finding counsel was not ineffective for failing to consult an independent forensic pathologist, a medical examiner, or a homicide-reconstruction expert.Â  We disagree.
At trial, the State presented the expert testimony of Dr. Wren, the pathologist who performed Harrisonâ€™s autopsy.Â  Dr. Wren testified that Harrison was shot three times: once through the hand, once through the front abdomen, and once through the back.Â  Dr. Wren stated that all three were distant gunshot wounds, meaning that when fired, the gun was at least twelve inches from the victim.
Defense counsel did not call an expert to rebut Dr. Wrenâ€™s testimony.Â  Instead, the defense presented Simpson as its sole witness.Â  Simpson testified that the shooting occurred during a struggle over the gun.Â  During closing argument, defense counsel reenacted Simpsonâ€™s testimony, showing the jury three possible theories regarding the trajectory of the bullets. 
At the PCR hearing, defense counsel testified that he did not see a need for calling an expert witness to refute Dr. Wrenâ€™s testimony.Â  But to show that there was in fact a need for such testimony, PCR counsel called three expert witnesses to the stand.Â  Two of the experts testified that Harrison was shot in the hand while he was gripping the barrel of Simpsonâ€™s gun, which supported Simpsonâ€™s testimony that the shots were fired during a struggle. Â But one expert testified that Harrison could have been shot in the back while lying on the ground or he could have been shot in the back while standing upright and fleeing.Â  
After considering this testimony, the PCR court found that defense counsel was not deficient in failing to consult an expert.Â  The court viewed the allegations against counsel as relating less with trial strategy and more to the degree that counsel should go in pursuing a defense theory.Â  In addition, the court found that even if counsel was deficient, there was no prejudice.Â  The judge found that the expert testimony presented at the PCR hearing added little either factually or theoretically, and did not negate the fact that all of the elements necessary for a murder conviction were present.Â  Therefore, the PCR court found that there was not a reasonable probability the added testimony would have changed the outcome of the guilt phase of the trial.Â  
â€œ[C]ounsel has a duty to make reasonable investigations or to make a reasonable decision that makes particular investigations unnecessary.â€Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 691 (1984).Â  A decision â€œnot to investigate must be directly assessed for reasonableness in all the circumstances, applying a heavy measure of deference to counselâ€™s judgments.â€Â  Id.Â  When counselâ€™s performance falls below this standard, a â€œdefendant must show that there is reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different.â€Â  Id. at 694.Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome.â€Â  Id.
We agree with the PCR court and find that counsel was not deficient in failing to consult a forensic expert.Â  It is clear from the record that counselâ€™s primary strategy was to prove that the shooting occurred during a struggle, and that this struggle somehow negated or lessened Simpsonâ€™s criminal liability for Harrisonâ€™s death.Â  However, evidence that Harrison grabbed Simpson by the shirt collar does nothing to explain how and why the gun was pulled from Simpsonâ€™s waist.Â  Additionally, Simpson himself testified to intentionally shooting a wounded Harrison twice after the alleged struggle concluded, once in Harrisonâ€™s back.Â  Even if Simpsonâ€™s testimony about the struggle was corroborated with expert testimony, there is not a reasonable probability that the jury would not have found Simpson guilty of murder. [1] 
Accordingly, we hold that the PCR court properly held that counsel was not ineffective in failing to consult an independent forensic pathologist, a medical examiner, or a homicide-reconstruction expert.[2]Â  
II.Â Â Â Â  Brady Violation
Simpson contends that the PCR court erred in denying relief due to the Stateâ€™s failure to disclose potentially exculpatory evidence related to the armed-robbery charge.Â  We agree.
The armed-robbery charge served as an aggravating circumstance that allowed the State to seek the death penalty.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 (1976).Â  Accordingly, it was essential for the State to prove that Simpson actually robbed the store.Â  
When police arrived at the scene of the crime, they noticed that the cash register drawer was open, and there were bills in every slot except the slot that would normally contain twenty-dollar bills.Â  Police also found a bag of money behind the counter, near the register.Â  Instead of preserving the bag and disclosing its existence to Simpsonâ€™s counsel, the police gave the bag to the victimâ€™s brother, Jack Harrison, who helped run the store.
The PCR court found: 

  The turning over of the bag by law enforcement clearly constitutes sloppy police work in an armed robbery investigation and could be considered a tainting of the scene.Â  Clearly the contents of the bag could have been exculpatory.Â  Clearly this evidence should have been preserved and, thus, been subject to discovery by [Simpson].

Despite this finding, the court ruled that the issue about the bag of money was not preserved for review because Simpson did not specifically raise it in his PCR application.Â  We disagree.
At the PCR hearing, two witnesses were called to testify about the money issue.Â  The first witness was Simpsonâ€™s defense counsel, who testified that he learned about the bag of money only two hours before testifying.Â  The second witness was Jack Harrison, whom the State called for the specific purpose of addressing the money issue.Â  Jack testified that the money was used to cash customersâ€™ checks, and it was unusual for money to be taken from the register and put into the bag.Â  
Given this testimony and the PCR courtâ€™s ruling on the issue relating to the bag of money, we hold that Simpson should have been permitted to amend his PCR application to conform to the evidence presented. See Rule 15(b), SCRCP (pleadings may be amended, even after judgment, to conform to issues tried by express or implied consent but not raised in the original pleadings); Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d 834, 843 (1992) (amendments must conform to evidence presented at trial, not raise new claims).Â  Moreover, we hold that the State would not be prejudiced by such an amendment given that the State cross-examined Simpsonâ€™s defense counsel on the issue and was permitted to present its own witness, Jack Harrison, to contest the issueâ€™s relevance.Â  See Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 313, 566 S.E.2d 529, 535 (2002) (amendments should be liberally allowed when no prejudice to the opposing party will result). 
Turning to the merits, we hold that the Stateâ€™s failure to tell the defense that a bag of money was found behind the counter prejudiced Simpsonâ€™s case in the penalty phase.Â  â€œ[T]he suppression by the prosecution of evidence favorable to an accused upon request violates due process where the evidence is material either to guilt or to punishment, irrespective of the good faith or bad faith of the prosecution.â€ Brady v. State of Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 87 (1963).Â  A Brady claim is complete if the accused can demonstrate (1) the evidence was favorable to the accused, (2) it was in the possession of or known to the prosecution, (3) it was suppressed by the prosecution, and (4) it was material to guilt or punishment.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 659, 594 S.E.2d 462, 470 (2004).Â  Favorable evidence is material if there is a reasonable probability that, had the evidence been disclosed to the defense, the result of the proceeding would have been different.Â  Id. at 660, 594 S.E.2d at 470.Â

  Does a capital defendant have a right under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution to offer evidence and argument in support of a residual-doubt claim - that is, that the jury in a penalty-phase proceeding should consider doubt about the defendantâ€™s guilt in deciding whether to impose the death penalty?

Even without a Guzek argument or charge, it is entirely possible that a weaker guilt case would result in a life sentence.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Mar-Reece Aldean Hughes, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26115
Heard October 19, 2005 - Filed February 13, 2006

REMANDED


  
    
      
        Teresa L. Norris, of the Center for Capital Litigation, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We are asked to decide whether Mar-Reece Aldean Hughes (Petitioner), who has been sentenced to die for the murder of a police officer, is mentally competent to waive his statutory right to pursue post-conviction relief (PCR) and be executed forthwith.Â  We conclude Petitioner is not mentally competent at this time to waive his right to pursue PCR.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner was convicted of murder, armed robbery, criminal conspiracy, possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, and possession of a stolen vehicle at a trial in York County in September 1995.Â  The jury found as an aggravating circumstance that the victim was a local law enforcement officer performing his official duties.Â  Petitioner was sentenced to death.Â  This Court affirmed the convictions and sentence.Â  State v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999), cert denied, Hughes v. South Carolina, 529 U.S. 1025 (2000). 
The convictions arose from the fatal shooting of police officer Brent McCants on September 25, 1992.Â  Petitioner and Eric Forney, armed with a gun, accosted two college students in the parking lot of a restaurant in Charlotte, North Carolina, and stole their car.Â  The two men then drove to Rock Hill where Officer McCants stopped them for driving without headlights. Â McCants was shot several times and his police-issue walkie-talkie was taken from his belt as he lay on the side of the road. Â Petitioner and Forney were apprehended shortly thereafter.Â  Hughes, 336 S.C. at 589, 521 S.E.2d at 502.
The State sought the death penalty against both Petitioner and Forney. Â They were tried separately. Â At his trial, Forney claimed Petitioner was the triggerman. Â Forney was convicted of murder, criminal conspiracy, and armed robbery and was acquitted of possession of a pistol during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Forney was sentenced to life imprisonment after the jury failed to return a unanimous verdict in the sentencing phase, and the convictions and sentences were affirmed on appeal.Â  State v. Forney, 321 S.C. 353, 468 S.E.2d 641 (1996).Â  At Petitionerâ€™s trial, Petitioner admitted he participated in the armed robbery of the vehicle and that he was driving at the time McCants stopped them, but claimed Forney shot McCants from the passenger seat and stole the officerâ€™s walkie-talkie.
On May 11, 2000, we remanded Petitionerâ€™s case to the circuit court for a competency hearing after Petitioner wrote the Attorney General requesting to waive further proceedings and be executed.Â  Petitioner changed his mind before a competency hearing was held and filed a post-conviction relief (PCR) application on September 21, 2000.Â  Less than a week later, Petitioner filed a pro se motion requesting counsel be relieved and he be executed.
After a court-ordered evaluation but before a competency hearing, Petitioner again changed his mind and decided to pursue PCR.Â  A competency hearing began on February 25, 2002, but was continued because Petitioner had been forcibly medicated in violation of a court order.Â  Petitioner indicated to counsel during a recess in the hearing that he wished to waive his right to PCR and be executed.Â  Petitionerâ€™s mental status was re-evaluated and a competency hearing was held in April 2002.
Judge Paul E. Short, Jr. on September 18, 2002, ruled Petitioner was competent to waive his right to counsel and PCR and competent to be executed.Â  An appeal of that ruling was pending before us when, acting sua sponte on March 7, 2003, we ordered Petitionerâ€™s appeal be held in abeyance pending a decision in Council v. Catoe, 359 S.C. 120, 597 S.E.2d 782 (2004).Â  We subsequently held in Council that a mentally incompetent PCR applicant is not entitled to a stay of proceedings pending a determination of his competency to proceed.Â  Instead, a mentally incompetent applicant and his counsel are required to pursue PCR on issues which do not require the applicantâ€™s assistance.Â  The applicant will have an opportunity to raise fact-based issues requiring his assistance at a later PCR proceeding if he regains competence.Â  Id. at 125-30, 597 S.E.2d at 785-87.
On June 25, 2004, we remanded the case to circuit court for another hearing on whether Petitioner is presently competent to waive his right to pursue PCR and whether that decision is knowing and voluntary pursuant to the standard established in Singleton v. State, 313 S.C. 75, 437 S.E.2d 53 (1993).
A competency hearing was held on September 15, 2004, before Judge Paul M. Burch following two court-ordered evaluations.Â  Judge Burch on September 24, 2004, ruled Petitioner is presently competent under the Singleton standard to waive his right to PCR and his decision was knowing and voluntary. Â 
ISSUE

  Did the circuit court err in ruling that Petitioner is mentally competent to waive his right to pursue PCR with counselâ€™s assistance and that his decision to do so was knowing and voluntary?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
This Court is charged with the responsibility of issuing a notice authorizing the execution of a person who has been duly convicted in a court of law and sentenced to death.Â  The Court will issue an execution notice after that person either has exhausted all appeals and other avenues of post-conviction relief in state and federal courts, or after that person, who is determined by this Court to be mentally competent, knowingly and voluntarily waives such appeals.Â  See In re Stays of Execution in Capital Cases, 321 S.C. 544, 471 S.E.2d 140 (1996); Roberts v. Moore, 332 S.C. 488, 505 S.E.2d 593 (1998); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-370 (2003) and Â§ 16-3-25 (2003).Â  When considering a request by an appellant who has been sentenced to death to waive the right to appeal or pursue PCR, and to be executed forthwith, it has been our practice to remand the matter to circuit court for a hearing and ruling on whether the appellant is mentally competent to make such a waiver, and whether any waiver of appellate or PCR rights is knowing and voluntary.Â  We remand such a matter when we deem it necessary to further develop or explore the facts of a case.Â  Following that competency hearing, the parties are required by this Court to file briefs and an appendix containing the testimony and evidence considered by the circuit court.Â  The appellant is required, when directed by the Court, to appear at oral argument and personally respond to questions regarding the waiver of his appellate or PCR rights.Â  See State v. Passaro, 350 S.C. 499, 567 S.E.2d 862 (2002); State v. Torrence, 317 S.C. 45, 451 S.E.2d 883 (1994) (Torrence II); Singleton v. State, 313 S.C. 75, 437 S.E.2d 53 (1993).
This procedure is necessary and appropriate because it provides the parties an opportunity to fully explore the issues and develop a record for our review.Â  We are not bound by the circuit courtâ€™s findings or rulings, although we recognize the circuit court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cf. Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280 S.E.2d 541 (1981).Â  This matter is similar to one arising in our original jurisdiction because it is this Court which must finally determine whether a particular appellant is mentally competent to make a knowing and voluntary waiver of his appellate or PCR rights.Â  Passaro, 350 S.C. at 506, 567 S.E.2d at 866 (â€œImportantly, this Court is the final body to decide whether to grant [an appellantâ€™s] waiver.â€); State v. Torrence, 322 S.C. 475, 477 n.2, 473 S.E.2d 703, 705 n.2 (1996) (Torrence III) (no appeal lies from the remand of case for fact finding on the issue of competency; such a case is similar to one arising in the Courtâ€™s general jurisdiction in which the Court may provide for fact finding as necessary). 
In deciding the issue of an appellantâ€™s competency, we carefully and thoroughly review the appellantâ€™s history of mental competency; the existence and present status of mental illness or disease suffered by the appellant, if any, as shown in the record of previous proceedings and in the competency hearing; the testimony and opinions of mental health experts who have examined the appellant; the findings of the circuit court which conducted a competency hearing; the arguments of counsel; and the appellantâ€™s demeanor and personal responses to our questions at oral argument regarding the waiver of appellate and PCR rights.Â  See Passaro, 350 S.C. at 504-08, 567 S.E.2d at 865-67 (reviewing evidence presented at competency hearing, including testimony of mental health experts, as well as appellantâ€™s responses to Courtâ€™s extensive questioning of him at oral argument, in concluding he was mentally competent to waive right to direct appeal and be executed); Torrence III, 322 S.C. 475, 473 S.E.2d 703 (after reviewing the record of a competency hearing in circuit court which included testimony from mental health experts and the record of the Courtâ€™s prior questioning of appellant, Court concluded the record â€œoverwhelmingly supports a determination that [appellant] is indeed competentâ€ to knowingly and voluntarily waive his appellate rights and be executed); Torrence II, 317 S.C. 45, 451 S.E.2d 883 (where appellant wished to waive right to direct appeal, Court remanded case for circuit court to conduct a competency hearing â€œallowing the introduction of testimony, exhibits, and evidence, to provide a full record for this Courtâ€™s evaluationâ€; Court questioned appellant personally about the waiver of his appellate rights and instructed circuit court to do the same); Singleton, 313 S.C. at 84, 437 S.E.2d at 58 (after reviewing record of competency hearing in circuit court which revealed, inter alia, the appellant was completely unaware he would die in an electric chair and was able to give only yes-no answers to questions, Court concluded â€œ[t]he record contains a wealth of evidence which supports the PCR judgeâ€™s finding of incompetenceâ€ and thus appellant could not be executed).Â  We necessarily decide each case on an individual basis, and it is within our discretion whether to allow an appellant to waive his appellate or PCR rights.Â  Passaro, 350 S.C. at 506, 567 S.E.2d at 866.
LAW AND ANALYSIS
I.Â  MENTAL COMPETENCY
Petitioner[1] contends the circuit court erred in ruling that he was mentally competent to waive his right to pursue PCR with counselâ€™s assistance and that his waiver was knowing and voluntary.Â  Petitioner argues his history of mental health problems, past and present evaluations by mental health professionals, and evidence at the most recent competency hearing support exactly the opposite conclusion - that he is not mentally competent to make a knowing and voluntary waiver of his right to pursue PCR.Â  We agree.
The standard for determining whether an appellant or PCR applicant is mentally competent to waive the right to a direct appeal or PCR is set forth in Singleton, 313 S.C. 75, 437 S.E.2d 53:

  The first prong is the cognitive prong which can be defined as:Â  whether a convicted defendant can understand the nature of the proceedings, what he or she was tried for, the reason for the punishment, or the nature of the punishment.Â  The second prong is the assistance prong which can be defined as:Â  whether the convicted defendant possesses sufficient capacity or ability to rationally communicate with counsel. 

Id. at 83, 437 S.E.2d at 58; accord Torrence II, 317 S.C. 45, 451 S.E.2d 883.Â  This standard of competency is the same standard required before a convicted defendant may be executed.Â  Torrence II, 317 S.C. at 47, 451 S.E.2d at 884. Â The failure of either prong is sufficient to warrant a stay of execution and a denial of the convicted defendantâ€™s motion to waive his right to appeal or pursue PCR.Â  Singleton, 313 S.C. at 83, 437 S.E.2d at 58.
The record sets forth Petitionerâ€™s mental health history from his arrest in 1992 until a competency hearing in 2002, as well as his pretrial murder of a cellmate by stabbing him to death during a psychotic episode in which he was deemed legally insane.Â  The record shows Petitioner exhibited signs of schizophrenia since at least the murder of Officer McCants in 1992, and perhaps a few years earlier.Â  He was first formally diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia in 1994.Â  Petitioner has experienced serious mental health problems for years, with sporadic treatment by medication and limited success in resolving them.
Petitioner was deemed legally competent to stand trial in 1994 by one examiner, then deemed incompetent by that same examiner and two others a short while later.Â  He was ruled legally competent by the court to stand trial in 1995 while being forcibly medicated, but stopped voluntarily taking his medications after he was sentenced to death.[2]Â  Examiners disagreed on whether Petitioner was competent in 2000, but court-appointed examiners found him to be incompetent to waive PCR in 2001.Â  A continued hearing resulted in further disagreement over Petitionerâ€™s competence among mental health practitioners, but a finding of competence by the circuit court in 2002.
Petitioner stated he wished to waive PCR in 2000, then changed his mind and filed a PCR application.Â  He again tried to waive PCR later in 2000, but again changed his mind and decided to pursue PCR in 2001.Â  He expressed his wish for PCR at a hearing in 2002, then changed his mind and indicated a renewed desire to waive it.
At the most recent competency hearing in September 2004, held upon order of this Court, the circuit court considered the transcript of two commitment hearings before the probate court in 2003, the testimony and reports of several psychiatrists who examined Petitioner, and the testimony of Petitioner.
At the first probate court hearing in January 2003, the probate judge ordered the South Carolina Department of Corrections (DOC) to treat Petitioner at DOCâ€™s Gilliam Psychiatric Hospital instead of housing him at a maximum security prison.Â  The probate court adhered to a previous order by the circuit court to forcibly medicate Petitioner only when deemed necessary on an emergency basis by DOC doctors and approved by Dr. Donna Schwartz-Watts, a private psychiatrist who has treated Petitioner for several years.Â  Schwartz-Watts and Dr. Richard Ellison, a DOC psychiatrist, testified Petitioner suffers from paranoid schizophrenia.Â  Petitioner has â€œbizarre thoughts about life and the afterlife,â€ hallucinations, and delusions.Â  Petitioner repeatedly flushed his clothes down the toilet and stood naked in his cell, smeared feces on the walls and himself, and postured bizarrely in his cell like a bodybuilder.
A Gilliam hospital social worker testified Petitioner was delusional.Â  Petitioner stated he had exploded bombs in several rooms, he could tell time by using his pulse, and he planned to be released from prison before Christmas and go to the bus station. 
The record is replete with evidence of the love-hate relationship Petitioner has with his appellate attorney, Teresa Norris.Â  For example, Petitioner at this probate court hearing offered a rambling, hateful, profanity-laced diatribe against Norris, his doctors, and the courts.Â  Petitioner accused Norris of representing him only to advance her career and said he has tried to fire her.Â  Petitioner repeatedly denied he was incompetent and said Norrisâ€™s only goal is to have him declared incompetent to prevent his execution.
At the second probate court hearing in May 2003, the psychiatristsâ€™ testimony and result was much the same, with the probate court ordering Petitioner to be transferred again to Gilliam Psychiatric Hospital for treatment.Â  Dr. Schwartz-Watts testified Petitioner was schizophrenic and severely mentally ill.Â  The doctor and a DOC social worker testified Petitioner had stopped eating or bathing, refused medications, torn up several jumpsuits, stayed in a fetal position under his cot, and was generally unable to care for himself.Â  While normally not violent, Petitioner can become extremely agitated and combative.Â  Before the judge entered the courtroom at this hearing, Petitioner picked up the table while in handcuffs and had to be restrained by several officers.Â  Dr. Schwartz-Watts testified Petitioner was trapped in an ever-deteriorating cycle of mental illness, taking medication and improving slightly, then going off medication and getting progressively worse.Â  Dr. Schwartz-Watts testified that

  [h]e needs medication, but to get him well enough to even know what he would want when heâ€™s well, what kinds of medication he would need to be maintained on, weâ€™ve never gotten to that point.Â  I have never been to the point with [Petitioner] that I have been able to sit down and rationally understand what he wants because heâ€™s never been well long enough to be able to do that.Â  Heâ€™s so ambivalent, which is a symptom of schizophrenia.Â  One week he wants to die.Â  The next week he would want to go on with his legal proceedings. 

At the competency hearing in September 2004, Drs. Jeffrey Musick, Pamela Crawford, and Margaret Melikian, psychiatrists employed by the South Carolina Department of Mental Health (DMH), all testified Petitioner was not competent under the Singleton standard.[3]Â  The three psychiatrists diagnosed Petitioner as suffering from undifferentiated schizophrenia, which is believed to be caused by a chemical imbalance in the brain.Â  The characteristic symptoms of this major mental illness are delusions, hallucinations, disorganization of speech and thoughts, and disorganization of behavior.
In applying the Singleton analysis, the three psychiatrists testified Petitioner understands factually that he was tried for the murder of a police officer.Â  Petitioner seemed to understand the reason for the punishment, i.e., that he murdered someone, although he also asserted racial bias and the Stateâ€™s wish to dissect his superior physical body as reasons for his punishment. 
The three psychiatrists testified Petitioner does not understand the nature of a PCR proceeding or the nature of the punishment.Â  In perhaps the most significant and serious deficiency, they concluded Petitioner does not possess sufficient capacity or ability to rationally communicate with his lawyer. 
The three psychiatrists testified Petitioner does not believe he is mentally ill, but sane and rational.Â  However, their examinations revealed he is actively psychotic, suffering from visual and auditory hallucinations, delusions, and an inability to engage in organized speech or thought.Â  His conversations usually are incoherent, with occasional, seemingly rational comments dominated by unintelligible, wildly divergent, and irrelevant dialogue peppered with made-up words and references to non-existent places.Â  The psychiatrists offered the following examples of delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech, thoughts, and behavior by Petitioner:

  Petitioner discussed something he called â€œhesitancy,â€ then in an incoherent monologue in which he moved to different topics in rapid succession, he discussed movies; Gandhi; â€œTel-Avery,â€ which he said was the worldâ€™s largest city; the equinox; the Tropic of Cancer; Venus Solaris; the synthetic god; the human god; the flesh god; and the cloth god. 
  
  Petitioner described himself as a world-class athlete who once could run 300 miles a week.Â  One reason the State wants to put him to death is to dissect his body to discover the reason for his athletic prowess.
  
  Petitioner said he has an intelligence quotient, or IQ, of 172; he also stated this fact to the judge at the 2004 competency hearing.[4]
  
  Petitioner refused to discuss what happens in a PCR proceeding, saying only that he had waived it and had no further comment.Â  He did, however, assert that the number of hours in his day, of which there are thirty-six or thirty-eight, will affect the PCR proceeding.Â  Other peopleâ€™s days contain only twelve hours. Â Â 
  
  Petitioner said there is no afterlife, but then said he would be transformed into an â€œeternal force.â€ 
  
  Petitioner said some people prepare for death by taking flu shots, although he is not one of them.
  
  Petitioner said medications are administered by white people to black people, particularly young black males, in order to control or incapacitate them.
  
  Petitioner has episodes in which he tears up his clothes and blankets, smears feces on the walls of his cell in patterns, bangs on his door, jumps on his bed, refuses to eat, speak, or bathe, and believes the staff is poisoning his food.
  
  Petitioner said the FBI runs a concentration camp at the prison.Â  
  
  Petitioner said he passes through time zones.Â  He often is Â fixated on numbers and the â€œhundreds of millionsâ€ of suns whose sunbeams awake unsuspecting women.Â  He believes â€œforcesâ€ enter and depart from his prison cell.Â  The forces awarded him â€œblack diamondsâ€ in his eyes, but took those away because he did not deserve them.Â  The forces instead gave him â€œblue ringsâ€ in his eyes, which he insisted on asking psychiatrists to examine by leaning forward and asking, â€œCan you see them?â€Â  The forces were responsible for removing a building from the prison grounds.Â  The forces have offered him 100 million years of life, but he turned them down in a respectful manner. 
  
  Petitioner said he wrote to former Secretary of State Madeline Albright at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue because he must communicate through her in order to convince the Supreme Court he is competent. 
  
  Petitioner stated that a major participant in a PCR proceeding is the â€œnotary republic,â€ which he defined as a â€œvalidated clerk that goes state to state and fills different positions.â€Â  A new â€œnotary republicâ€ must be chosen to serve in his case because the licenses of all â€œnotary republicsâ€ around the world will expire this year.Â  
  
  Petitioner said death means death, but seconds later asserted he has been granted five million years of life.Â  
  
  Petitioner said Judge Short told him that his mother was a whore during the first competency hearing in 2002.
  
  Petitioner said he is being punished because he owns the state of South Carolina and the State wants to confiscate his wealth.Â  He further asserted he made $56 million the previous week.Â  
  
  Petitioner said he is a god and described jousting with other gods. 

Petitionerâ€™s testimony at the hearing is informative only because it reinforces the psychiatristsâ€™ diagnoses and opinions.Â  Petitioner left the courtroom as the hearing began, upset that his usual guardian was not present and railing against â€œcrackersâ€ who are bent on medicating him against his will.Â  He later returned. 
Neither the Stateâ€™s attorney nor Judge Burch was able to elicit coherent or rational responses from Petitioner, including repeated questions about the nature of a PCR proceeding.Â  Petitioner brushed aside questions and, in profanity-laced statements, asserted he was a â€œsane, rational individualâ€ who â€œyou white folks always want to medicate me on drugs down here.â€Â  He told examiners â€œI am no donor and wish to be electrocuted,â€ â€œyou donâ€™t like the fact that Iâ€™m no donor.Â  I ainâ€™t going to be no donor.â€[5]Â  He stated he wanted to be executed by electrocution, complained that he had done his â€œlegal four hours in chains,â€ and repeatedly asked to be taken back to his cell.
At his appearance before this Court, Petitioner answered most of our questions calmly and politely.Â  Attorneys involved with his case for several years stated they were surprised by Petitionerâ€™s restrained demeanor. Â Petitioner chose not to remain in the courtroom to hear the attorneysâ€™ oral arguments, but was returned to Gilliam Psychiatric Hospital, where he has been incarcerated for 2Â½ years.Â  
Petitioner testified he is not mentally ill, but merely withdrawn or voluntarily silent because he has been isolated in a cell by himself for years.Â  He expressed his wish to die by electrocution and testified that death means the brain and other bodily organs cease to function.Â  Respondent testified he occasionally takes â€œGeodorn,â€ which he described as a mild sedative which helps him sleep, but he has not taken it in about week.[6]
Petitioner often responded with yes-no answers when asked about theÂ  nature of various rights he would be waiving and the consequences of his waiver.Â  When asked to elaborate on an answer in his own words, Petitionerâ€™s responses revealed a distinct lack of understanding of the PCR process, substantial confusion about his appellate rights, and disorganized thought patterns.Â  The following exchanges during the questioning of Petitioner by Chief Justice Toal are instructive:

  Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you understand what a post conviction relief Â proceeding is?
  A:Â  Yes, I do.
  Q:Â  Do you understand what happens in a post conviction
  Â relief proceeding?
  A:Â  Yes.Â  Yes, I do.
  Q:Â  Has your attorney explained to you what happens in a post conviction relief proceeding?
  A:Â  She has several times.
  Q:Â  And do you understand what your attorney has told you
  Â about that?
  A:Â  I pretty much have taken it in.Â  I pretty much have
  Â taken it in.
  Q:Â  Tell me in your own words, Mr. Hughes, what happens
  Â in a post conviction relief proceeding.
  A:Â  That means that I can take up the terms and the amendments thatâ€™s being held before me to take and perceive the law, as in perceivance.
  . . .
  Q:Â  All right, sir.Â  Do you realize that by waiving your Â right to post conviction relief, you may be jeopardizing Â any habeas corpus relief that would be available to you in Â a federal court?
  A:Â  Well, Iâ€™m not jeopardizing the habeas corpus law because the Mecklenburg County Jail, when they took and gave me ten years for grand theft auto larceny, they took and convened the court then.Â  They took and changed the jurisdiction, so thatâ€™s under habeas corpus law.Â  Theyâ€™ve already taken and did that, so Iâ€™m not under habeas corpus law.
  The state of North Carolina willingly did take in and get with the legal system down here in that matter of conveyance.
  . . .
  Q:Â  Now, do you believe you received a fair trial, Mr. Hughes?
  A:Â  Well, itâ€™s not to my belief in the law or the legal system.Â  As far as to merit, when I took and did my first summary, when I did my procumfactories (phonetic) all the way down to the final summary, in point factory - the case in factory, the court didnâ€™t have any evidence against me.Â  When the court didnâ€™t have any evidence against me, they showed me what their attitude was all about.
  Q:Â  All right, sir.
  A:Â  The court showed me, first of all, that on its legal terms, that they did not respect my ability to think.Â  When I took and did my summary, it wasnâ€™t that they took in a sorry day of intelligence, itâ€™s just the fact that they didnâ€™t have any case against me.
  As I have stated over the years and stuff, being that Iâ€™m a person of my own degree, that means Iâ€™m a person of my own understanding, itâ€™s not that I have a problem with my conscience because my conscience does not deal with me - deal with me pertaining to this case.
   I said when I had went into the courtroom, the court, first of all, made like it was an understanding as far as to what was presented on the record, and what was presented on the record, they could not have found me guilty.
  Again as I stated, over the years since I have been incarcerated, I said that to myself, if they did come up, well, the cases in fact raise or misses in point they had to convict me to have a life sentence, I still would have to have did (sic) about 30 or 40 years.
  If it had been a migrating (sic) circumstance, it still would have been the points that might have happened inside of this state, but as far as dealing with other peopleâ€™s backgrounds, other peopleâ€™s attitudes, like I said, I have always been a person who did solitary time.Â  I was being in segregated law.
  As far as for incarcerated time, Iâ€™ll always be in segregation, other than the fact that when I had took (sic) and went to North Carolina, they have - you know, being incarcerated, segregated, as I said, they did not take and value what I put down on paper.Â  On those conditions there, I told judge Burch that I was guilty on those conditions there.
   Q:Â  I understand.Â  I understand, Mr. Hughes.
  A:Â  So it doesnâ€™t have anything to do with legal phasing as to innocent or guilt.Â  It didnâ€™t have anything to do with that.Â  Iâ€™m saying it had went through this court system here about four years ago one time before when I had took and brought the procedure about six years ago to be executed.
  As I have stated, Iâ€™ve been waiting over six years now in my own room to be executed.Â  I have been waiting six years to be executed.Â  Do you understand?Â  I havenâ€™t been just sitting here thinking about being executed for no reason.Â  I've been waiting six years to be executed with finality.
  Q:Â  All right, sir.
  A:Â  In the courtroom decision back then, when they took and changed the legal law, the public back then, because she had an expired commission, I think it was every four years.Â  That was the first setback that I had took and went through.
  Other than that, if I didnâ€™t give you a runaround story, it was just to this fact here.Â  When I had went through the courtroom through the preliminary hearings in North - I mean, not North Carolina but in York County close to North Carolina, they did not take and listen to what was presented in the case.Â  They just presented their case.
  I offered those things right there.Â  I took and formed my own opinion about the state of South Carolina, but I have never came to the courtroom as showing a negative attitude.Â  I never did that, even though my attitude is negative toward the court system.

Petitionerâ€™s mention of a â€œpublic back then,â€ a â€œsheâ€ who had an â€œexpired commission,â€ appears to be a reference to what he previously has described as a â€œnotary republic,â€ a person whom Petitioner has told psychiatrists is a major participant in a PCR proceeding.Â  In addition, Petitioner twice told us that he has written to former Secretary of State Madeline Albright, whom he previously has indicated wields some influence over our resolution of his case.
We have carefully and thoroughly reviewed Petitionerâ€™s history of mental competency, as well as his history of mental illness as shown in the record of previous proceedings and in the last competency hearing.Â  We have considered the testimony of the mental health experts who examined Petitioner.Â  We have reviewed the findings of the circuit court and weighed the arguments of counsel for the parties, and we have considered Petitionerâ€™s demeanor and personal responses to our questions at oral argument regarding the waiver of his rights.Â  We recognize, of course, that questions of mental competence, unlike issues of historical fact, call for a basically subjective judgment.Â  â€œAnd unlike the determination of whether the death penalty is appropriate in a particular case, the competency determination depends substantially on expert analysis in a discipline fraught with subtleties and nuances.â€Â  Ford v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 399, 426 (1986) (Powell, J., concurring) (quotes omitted).
We acknowledge the issue of Petitionerâ€™s mental competence is not immutable.Â  A determination of mental competence may change from one period of time to another, particularly when the administration of medication or treatment, or the lack thereof, may affect a personâ€™s mental faculties.Â  See e.g. Walton v. Angelone, 321 F.3d 442, 459 (4th Cir. 2003) (â€œEven if a defendant is mentally competent at the beginning of the trial, the trial court must continually be alert for changes which would suggest that he is no longer competent.â€); Hunter v. State, 660 So.2d 244, 248 (Fla. 1995) (once a defendant is determined competent to stand trial, a presumption of competence attaches to the defendant in later proceedings; however, another competency hearing is required if a bona fide question about the defendantâ€™s competency is raised); see also Drope v. Missouri, 420 U.S. 162, 180 (1975) (information concerning defendantâ€™s suicide attempt during trial, when considered with psychiatric information available prior to trial and wifeâ€™s testimony concerning his â€œstrange behaviorâ€ and his attempt to kill her shortly before trial, created sufficient doubt of defendantâ€™s competence to stand trial so as to require further inquiry on the issue).
We conclude that, pursuant to the Singleton standard, Petitioner is not mentally competent at this time to waive the right to pursue PCR.Â  Petitioner apparently understands what he was tried for and the reason for his punishment; whether he understands the nature of the punishment is less certain.Â  However, it is clear he does not understand the nature of the PCR proceeding which he wishes to waive the right to pursue.Â  Petitioner was not able to describe, in a reasonably coherent fashion using laymanâ€™s terms, the basic purposes or procedures available to him in PCR, either in the court below or in this Court.Â  Thus, the cognitive prong of the Singleton analysis has not been satisfied.
We further conclude the assistance prong is not satisfied on this record.Â  We are not persuaded Petitioner possesses sufficient capacity or ability to rationally communicate with counsel.Â  We agree with the mental health experts who examined Petitioner, and who cited his inability to communicate adequately with counsel as a primary reason for their conclusion he was not mentally competent.Â  Given our conclusions, it is not necessary to reach the issue of whether any waiver was knowing and voluntary. 
In a second argument, Petitioner asserts that, even if he were deemed mentally competent, the Eighth Amendment proscription against cruel and unusual punishment and international law prohibit the execution of a chronically mentally ill person.Â  We find it unnecessary to address this argument in light of our disposition of this matter.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
CONCLUSION
We conclude Petitioner is not mentally competent, pursuant to the Singleton standard, to waive the right to pursue PCR and be executed forthwith.Â  We remand this case to circuit court for further proceedings pursuant to Council v. Catoe, 359 S.C. 120, 597 S.E.2d 782 (2004).
REMANDED.
MOORE, WALLER, and PLEICONES, J.J., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.


Chief Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, Hughes is competent to waive his right to pursue PCR.Â  I disagree with the majorityâ€™s cherry-picking of the transcript and record.Â  Throughout this proceeding Hughes has demonstrated an ability to understand the impact of his decisions and, in my opinion, did so in his appearance before this Court.Â  
Further, in the interest of judicial economy, I would allow Hughes to waive his right to PCR.Â  In my view, allowing Hughes to waive his right to PCR would result in the case arriving at the exact same procedural posture as is now.Â  Ultimately, the majorityâ€™s decision will force the case to go full circle and eventually require a thorough evaluation to determine if Hughes is competent to be executed.Â  As a result, after the Order for Execution is issued, counsel for Hughes could apply for subsequent PCR relief pursuant to Singleton, which is the final judicial safeguard against executing someone not mentally competent.Â  Singleton, 313 S.C. 75, 87, 437 S.E.2d 53, 60 (1993) (stating that apply Â§ 17-27-20 is the final judicial safeguard for a stay of execution to evaluation a defendants competency and immediate review by this Court is permitted if the defendant is found competent by the PCR court); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-20(a)(6) (stating that a defendant may apply relief upon any ground of alleged error).Â  The decision of the majority adds an additional step, one that Hughes has requested that he be allowed to waive. 


[1]Â  We recognize Petitioner personally disagrees with the arguments set forth by his attorney.Â  Nevertheless, we will refer only to Petitioner (without distinguishing him from counsel) because he remains represented by counsel and the crucial issue is whether Petitioner has the mental capacity to waive his right to PCR and counsel, and make these decisions for himself.
[2]Â  The State may not forcibly medicate an inmate solely to facilitate execution.Â  An inmate has a right, grounded in the state constitutional right to privacy and the Fourteenth Amendmentâ€™s Due Process clause of the federal constitution, to be free from unwanted medical intrusions.Â  The State may forcibly medicate an inmate only when he is dangerous to himself or others, and then only when it is in the inmateâ€™s best medical interest.Â  Singleton, 313 S.C. at 89, 437 S.E.2d at 61 (relying in part on Riggins v. Nevada, 504 U.S. 127 (1992) and Washington v. Harper, 494 U.S. 210 (1990)); see also Ford v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 399, 418-27 (1986) (holding, in plurality opinion, that the execution of an inmate who becomes incompetent or insane after conviction and sentencing is violative of the Eighth Amendment and due process) (Powell, J., concurring).
[3]Â  Dr. Pratap Narayan, a DMH psychiatrist, offered similar testimony about Petitionerâ€™s statements and actions, but declined to offer an opinion on whether Petitioner was competent under the Singleton standard.
[4]Â  An IQ between 90 and 110 is considered average.Â  See http://www.bartleby.com/59/17/intelligence.html.
[5]Â  Melikian testified that by using the term â€œdonor,â€ Petitioner probably was referring to his desire that the State not dissect his body to discover the reasons for his purported athletic prowess.
[6]Â  Petitioner apparently meant â€œGeodon,â€ the brand name of ziprasidone, an anti-psychotic medication used to treat schizophrenia.Â  See Physicians Desk Reference 2688-89 (2002).

title: State v. Morgan
description: This criminal case involves the issue of whether appellant should be allowed to present evidence on a remand for re-sentencing that he is entitled to a sentence less than life imprisonment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Eric Dale Morgan, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26116
Heard January 17, 2006 - Filed February 21, 2006

 
VACATED AND
REMANDED 


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; and Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for respondent.
      
    
  


 ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Pursuant to Roper v. Simmons, 543 U.S. 551 (2005), we vacate appellantâ€™s sentence of death and remand to the trial court for re-sentencing.
FACTS
Appellant was charged with murder, armed robbery, and possession of an explosive device.Â  The charges resulted from the murder and armed robbery of a convenience store employee on May 3, 2000.Â  Appellant admitted shooting the victim once in the head as the victim was closing the store and then stealing a bag the victim was carrying that contained more than $7000.Â  Appellant and his accomplice, who had been hired at the store a week before the incident, had originally planned to blow a hole in the back wall of the store with a pipe-bomb after it closed.Â  Following a trial, appellant was found guilty as charged.
The State sought the death penalty, relying on two aggravating statutory circumstances:Â  (1) the murder occurred during the commission of an armed robbery, and (2) the murder occurred during the commission of larceny while armed with a deadly weapon.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(d) and (e) (2003).Â  At sentencing, the defense relied on three mitigating circumstances:Â  (1) the defendant had no significant history of prior criminal conviction involving the use of violence against another person; (2) the age or mentality of the defendant at the time of the crime; and (3) the defendant was below the age of eighteen at the time of the crime.Â  See Â§Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(1), (7), and (9) (2003).
The jury found both statutory aggravators and appellant was sentenced to death on the murder charge.Â  On the charge of armed robbery, appellant was sentenced to an imprisonment term of thirty years.Â  On the charge of possession of an explosive device, he was sentenced to an imprisonment term of fifteen years to be served consecutively to the armed robbery sentence.[1]Â  
Subsequently, the United States Supreme Court decided Roper v. Simmons, 543 U.S. 551 (2005).Â  The Roper court held that the execution of individuals who were under eighteen years of age at the time of their capital crimes is prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[2]Â  Accordingly, appellantâ€™s sentence of death is vacated. 
ISSUE

Should appellant be allowed to present evidence on a remand for re-sentencing that he is entitled to a sentence less than life imprisonment?

DISCUSSION
The parties disagree on the appropriate procedure on a remand for re-sentencing.Â  The State argues the matter should be remanded to the trial court for the sole purpose of sentencing appellant to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.Â  The State contends life without parole is the only alternate sentence because the jury found two aggravating circumstances.Â  The State bases its argument on the portion of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(A) (Supp. 2005) which states, â€œIf the State seeks the death penalty and a statutory aggravating circumstance is found beyond a reasonable doubt . . ., and a recommendation of death is not made, the trial judge must impose a sentence of life imprisonment.â€Â  The State argues that where it has sought the death penalty and the jury has found aggravating circumstances, the only available sentence other than death is life imprisonment.
Appellant, however, contends that, on remand, he should be allowed to argue that he should be sentenced to something less than life imprisonment without parole.Â  Appellant is correct.Â  Pursuant to Roper v. Simmons, supra, appellantâ€™s death sentence is prohibited.Â  The portion of Â§ 16-3-20(A) cited by the State does not apply to appellant.Â  Further, on remand, whether the jury found certain aggravating circumstances at his sentencing proceeding is irrelevant because the discussion of aggravators arises only when the State seeks the death penalty, which the State cannot do in this case.
We therefore look to Â§ 16-3-20(A) for guidance on how a person convicted of murder and who is not subject to the death penalty should be sentenced.Â  Section 16-3-20(A) provides that â€œ[a] person who is convicted of . . . murder must be punished by . . . imprisonment for life, or by a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment for thirty years.â€Â  Therefore, on remand, the trial court may receive additional evidence on the question of whether appellant is entitled to receive a sentence less than life imprisonment and decide on a sentence that ranges from a mandatory minimum imprisonment term of thirty years to life imprisonment.
VACATED AND REMANDED.
BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., Acting Justice Clyde N. Davis, Jr., and Acting Justice Edward B. Cottingham, concur.

[1]Appellantâ€™s sentences on the charges of armed robbery and possession of an explosive device are unaffected by this decision. 
[2] Both the State and appellant agree that appellant was seventeen years old at the time of the murder.Â  The record indicates appellantâ€™s birthday is May 19, 1982.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In re: Amendments to the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules

ORDER

Rule 410(e), SCACR, currently requires that any   member wishing to practice in the Unified Court System provide a current e-mail   address to the Bar, and promptly notify the Bar of any change of e-mail address.   The purpose of the requirement is to allow the Bar and the respective clerks of   court to quickly and efficiently communicate with members. Moreover, as the   practice of law becomes increasingly driven by technology, it is paramount that   all members have a current and valid e-mail address not only to facilitate   prompt communication, but so that the judiciary can begin implementing e-filing   procedures. 
 
However, it has recently come to the Court’s   attention that an unacceptable number of members have failed to provide the Bar   with their current e-mail addresses. Further, it is essential that all members,   not just those practicing in the Unified Court System, provide the Bar with   current e-mail address information.
Therefore, pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South   Carolina Constitution, we hereby amend Rule   410(e), South Carolina Appellate Court Rules, as set forth in the   attachment, to require that all members, other than retired members, provide the   Bar with a current e-mail address. Further, members are now required to update   change of address information within ten days of any such change. Members who   have not yet provided their current e-mail address shall submit that information   to the Bar by April 3, 2006. 
 
The amendment is effective immediately.

title: In the Matter of Greenville County Magistrate Don I. Hensley
description: This is an opinion in which the Court publicly reprimands a magistrate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Greenville County Magistrate Don I. Hensley,Respondent.
      
    
  



Opinion No. 26117
Submitted January 31, 2006 - Filed February 27, 2006

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Robert E. Bogan, Assistant Deputy Attorney General, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        David L. Thomas, of Greenville, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a public reprimand.Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
On June 6, 1989, respondent was appointed to serve as a Greenville County Magistrate.Â  Dorothy Campbell Crossley served as respondentâ€™s office manager from 1996 to January 2005.Â  On January 27, 2005, Crossley went to respondentâ€™s home before reporting to work and confessed she had been stealing money from respondentâ€™s office for five years.Â  
Crossley provided the following explanation concerning her thefts to ODC.Â  She reported that the banking deposit was customarily compiled between 4:30 and 5:00 p.m. and that, at this time, respondent was either not in the office or did not review the deposit.Â  Accordingly, unless she was absent from work or busy, Crossley was left with exclusive control over the daily deposits and associated documentation.Â  Knowing her work would not be reviewed, Crossley would occasionally take cash from the criminal deposit and reduce the amount of cash shown on the deposit ticket by the same amount, even though this left the deposit out of balance with the officeâ€™s computer-generated daily deposit listing. 
ODC examined financial records provided by respondentâ€™s office for the months of January, April, August, and December 2004.Â  The examination confirmed the pattern of embezzlement described by Crossley.Â  Using the practice described above, Crossley embezzled $8344.60 in those four months.Â  ODC is informed that an accounting conducted by the Greenville County Finance Department indicates respondentâ€™s office is missing approximately $96,500 and it appears this amount was taken by Crossley while working under respondentâ€™s supervision.Â  
This Courtâ€™s November 9, 1999 order provides:

  While the Court recognizes that magistrates must utilize employees of their office to assist in the handling of the monies of their office, each magistrate is personally responsible for compliance with all procedures for the handling of the monies of their magisterial office and proper record keeping related thereto and shall regularly, but no less than monthly, review bank statements and other records to insure such compliance.Â  

Respondent represents that he relied almost entirely on Crossley to properly document and disburse the monies in his office and that, prior to January 27, 2005, he had complete faith in Crossley and did not see the need to â€œgo behind herâ€ and check her work.Â  Respondent acknowledges that his supervision of Crossley did not comply with the requirements of the Courtâ€™s November 9, 1999 order and represents he has now implemented each of the oversights required by the order.Â  Respondent disputes any contention that his adherence to the order would have prevented Crossleyâ€™s embezzlement and has submitted affidavits in support of his belief that Crossley would have been successful in her embezzlement scheme even if all requirements of the November 9, 1999 order had been followed.Â  
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity of the judiciary); Canon 3 (judge shall perform the duties of office diligently); Canon 3(C)(1) (judge shall maintain professional competence in judicial administration); and Canon 3(C)(2) (judge shall require his staff to observe the standards of fidelity and diligence that apply to the judge). Â In addition, respondent admits that he has violated the Courtâ€™s November 9, 1999 order.Â  Respondent admits his misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct), Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to persistently fail to perform judicial duties or persistently perform judicial duties in an incompetent or neglectful manner), and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to willfully violate a valid order issued by a court of this state) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION 
We note respondent did not participate in the thefts reported by this opinion.Â  Moreover, he candidly reported the thefts and, thereby, his own misconduct, to ODC and fully cooperated with ODC in its investigation of this matter. Â Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

Capco
