THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      Capco of Summerville, Inc., Appellant,
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        J.H. Gayle Construction Company, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26118
Heard January 19, 2006 - Filed February 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John H. Tiller, of Haynsworth, Sinkler Boyd, PA, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Erin DuBose Dean, of Tupper, Grimsley & Dean, PA, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Â Capco of Summerville, Inc. (Capco) appeals an order of the circuit court holding its contribution action against respondent, J. H. Gayle Construction Company (Gayle), was barred by the statute of repose set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-640(6) (1986).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Capco owns Dixie Plaza Shopping Center in Colleton County.Â  The parking lot of the shopping center was constructed by Gayle and was substantially completed on November 1, 1986.Â  On May 19, 1996, Pauline Conner was involved in an automobile accident with James Hogan in the parking lot of Dixie Plaza.Â  Conner entered a settlement agreement with Hogan for $5000.00.Â  In August 1998, Conner and her husband filed lawsuits against Capco and Gayle, alleging negligent design and construction of the parking lot.Â  On June 13, 2003, Capco settled the Connersâ€™ claims for $500,000.00.Â  Although Gayle did not participate in the settlement, the settlement expressly released Gayle from any liability to the Conners.Â  
On September 22, 2003, Capco filed this contribution action against Gayle.Â  Gayle moved for summary judgment contending Capcoâ€™s claim was barred by the thirteen year statute of repose set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-640(6) (2005), as it was commenced seventeen years after completion of the parking lot.Â  Capco responded, contending the thirteen year statute of repose had been impliedly repealed by the Legislatureâ€™s adoption of the one-year limitation period set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-40(D) of the Uniform Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act.Â  The trial court held Â§ 15-3-640 (6) controlled such that Capcoâ€™s contribution action was barred.
The issue presented by Capco is whether S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-6-640(6) was implied repealed by the Legislatureâ€™s 1988 adoption of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-40(D), and whether the two statutes are irreconcilably conflicting.Â  Although we are deeply troubled by the result in this case, we are constrained to hold that the thirteen year period set forth in Â§ 15-6-640 (D) controls, such that the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Gayle.
LAW/ANALYSIS
At the time this action was commenced, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-640 (1986), provided:

  No actions to recover damages based upon or arising out of the defective or unsafe condition of an improvement to real property may be brought more than thirteen years after substantial completion of such an improvement. Â For purposes of this section, an action based upon or arising out of the defective or unsafe condition of an improvement to real property includes: 
  (6) an action for contribution or indemnification for damages sustained on account of an action described in this subdivision. 

However, the Uniform Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act (Contribution Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-40(D) (2005), which was enacted in 1988, provides that an action for contribution is barred unless a settling tortfeasor has â€œagreed while action is pending against him to discharge the common liability and has within one year after the agreement paid the liability and commenced his action for contribution.â€ Â Â Â 
In this case, Capco settled the pending case with the Conners on June 13, 2003, discharging the liability of both itself and Gayle, and brought this contribution suit three months later, well within the one year time period provided by Â§ 15-38-40(D).Â Â  However, although the contribution action was commenced within the one-year period set forth in the Contribution Act, it was not brought within 13 years of the substantial completion of the parking lot, as required by Â§ 15-3-640(6).Â Â  The circuit court, relying upon the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Florence County School District No. 2 v. Interkal, Inc., 348 S.C. 446, 559 S.E.2d 866 (Ct. App. 2002), held Â§ 15-3-640(6) controlled such that Capcoâ€™s contribution action was barred.Â  We agree.
In Interkal, a school bleacher collapsed in February 1991, injuring a student.Â  The bleachers had been installed in 1969 and 1971.Â  The student sued the school district and Interkal, the manufacturer of the bleachers.Â  The school district settled with the student, then sought contribution from Interkal under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-10 et. seq. (the Contribution Act).Â  The Court of Appeals held that â€œ[t]he Statute of Repose bars actions for contribution under the Uniform Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act brought more than thirteen years after the completion of an improvement to real property.â€Â  348 S.C. at 453, 559 S.E.2d at 869.Â  We find Interkal is clearly dispositive of the issue; accordingly, the trial court properly held the statute of repose applied to bar Capcoâ€™s action.
Notwithstanding the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Interkal, Capco asserts the two statutes are irreconcilably conflicting.Â  It contends the statute of repose was repealed by implication by adoption of the one-year period in the Contribution Act.Â  We disagree.Â  
Repeal by implication is disfavored, and is found only when two statutes are incapable of any reasonable reconcilement.Â  Mims v. Alston, 312 S.C. 311, 440 S.E.2d 357 (1994).Â  Moreover, the repugnancy must be plain, and if the two provisions can be construed so that both can stand, a court shall so construe them.Â  City of Rock Hill v. South Carolina DHEC, 302 S.C. 161, 167, 394 S.E.2d 327, 331 (1990).Â  Where there is one statute addressing an issue in general terms and another statute dealing with the identical issue in a more specific and definite manner, the more specific statute will be considered an exception to, or a qualifier of, the general statute and given such effect.Â  Wilder v. South Carolina Hwy. Depâ€™t, 228 S.C. 448, 90 S.E.2d 635 (1955).Â  See also Wooten ex rel. Wooten v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 333 S.C. 464, 468, 511 S.E.2d 355, 357 (1999) (a specific statutory provision prevails over a more general one); Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 558, 462 S.E.2d 858, 859 (1995) (general rule of statutory construction is that a specific statute prevails over a more general one).
A statute of limitations is a procedural device that operates as a defense to limit the remedy available from an existing cause of action. A statute of repose creates a substantive right in those protected to be free from liability after a legislatively determined period of time.Â  Langley v. Pierce, 313 S.C. 401, 403-04, 438 S.E.2d 242, 243 (1993).Â Â  A statute of repose is typically an absolute time limit beyond which liability no longer exists and is not tolled for any reason because to do so would upset the economic balance struck by the legislative body.Â  Id. at 404, 438 S.E.2d at 243.Â  A statute of repose is â€œ[a] statute barring any suit that is brought after a specified time since the defendant acted . . . even if this period ends before the plaintiff has suffered a resulting injury.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1451 (8th Ed. 2004).Â  â€œStatutes of repose by their nature impose on some plaintiffs the hardship of having a claim extinguished before it is discovered, or perhaps before it even exists.â€Â  Camachco v. Todd and Leiser Homes, 706 N.W.2d 49, 54, n. 6 (Minn. 2005) citing W. Page Keeton, et. al., Prosser and Keeton on the Law of Torts Â§ 30, p. 168 (5th ed.1984).Â  As noted by the Virginia Supreme Court, â€œ[a] statute of repose differs from a statute of limitations. . . . [T]he expiration of the time extinguishes not only the legal remedy but also all causes of action, including those which may later accrue as well as those already accrued.â€Â  School Bd. of the City of Norfolk v. U.S. Gypsum, 360 S.E.2d 325, 327-328 (VA. 1987).Â  
The statutes at issue do not irreconcilably conflict.Â  Section 15-3-640(6) is a statute of repose setting forth the outside time period in which an action arising out of the defective condition of an improvement to real property must be brought, which date begins to run from completion of the project.Â  Section 15-38-40(D), on the other hand, is a statute of limitations which governs contribution actions, and begins to run from the date of settling a common liability.Â  We find neither an irreconcilable conflict, nor an implied repeal of section 15-3-640(6).[1]
Moreover, section 15-3-640 (6) specifically applies to â€œan action for contribution or indemnification for damages sustained on account of an actionâ€ arising out of the defective or unsafe condition of an improvement to real property.Â  Section 15-38-40(D), on the other hand, applies generally to all contribution actions.Â  Given that section 15-3-640(6) applies not simply to contribution actions, but to this specific class of contribution actions, we find it is the more specific statute and therefore controls.Â  Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 558, 462 S.E.2d 858, 859 (1995) (general rule of statutory construction is that a specific statute prevails over a more general one).Â  See also State v. Life Ins. Co. of Georgia, 254 S.C. 286, 175 S.E.2d 203 (1970) (court will apply a more specific statute of limitations instead of a general one).[2]
CONCLUSION
We find Capcoâ€™s action is time-barred by the thirteen year time-period set forth in Â§ 15-3-640 (6).Â  However, we are troubled by the harsh result in the case.Â  As Capco correctly points out, where a lawsuit is filed on the eve of the running of the statute of repose, but is not resolved until after the statute has run, the contribution action will be barred before the right has even accrued, placing an undue burden on a single tortfeasor.Â  This is clearly contrary to the purposes of the Contribution Act, which was to â€œameliorate the unfairness vested on all joint tortfeasors by the common lawâ€™s prohibition against contribution.â€Â  Southeastern, 331 S.C. at 470, 443 S.E.2d at 397. Â However, although we are troubled by this result, we are not at liberty to rewrite the statutes, and any amendment must come from the Legislature.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000).Â  The trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Gayle is affirmed.
AFFIRMED. Â Â 
MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Clyde N. Davis, Jr., concur.

[1]Â  We note that Section 15-3-640 was amended in 2005 and now contains an outside limitation of eight years in which to file suit.Â  Notably, the 2005 amendment did not delete or otherwise amend subsection (6), clearly indicating the legislature did not intend to repeal this subsection.Â  2005 Act No. 27, Â§ 2, eff. July 1, 2005.
[2]Â  Capco asserts this case is analogous to Southeastern Freight Lines v. City of Hartsville, 313 S.C. 466, 443 S.E.2d 395 (1994), superseded by statute as stated in Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999).Â Â  In Southeastern, we held the Contribution Act, to the extent it provided unlimited pro rata liability for joint tortfeasors, was inconsistent with, and had effectively repealed those portions of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-100(c) and 15-78 120 (a)(1), which required apportioned liability and a limitation on damages against state agencies.Â  Southeastern is inapposite.Â  There, the limits on liability in the Tort Claims Act were inconsistent with unlimited pro rata liability.Â  Here, the statutes simply set forth time periods to establish when a claim is barred.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Angelica Seegars, John Doe, and L.J. Parker, Defendants,
        of whom Angelica Seegars is Appellant.
        IN RE: Brionica Jaâ€™zyra Seegars, 10-06-99; Javarus Kaleel Seegars,07-11-02; Children under the age of eighteen.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26119 
Heard February 2, 2006 - Filed February 27, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED 


  
    
      
        William P. Davis, of Baker, Ravanel & Bender, L.L.P., of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Deborah Murdock, of Greenville, for Respondent.
        Marion H. (Mark) Grier, Jr., of Lancaster, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Angelica Seegars (Appellant) appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights to Brionica Jaâ€™zyra Seegars and Javarus Kaleel Seegars (Children).Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 22, 2002, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) took Children into emergency protective custody because Javarus had been hospitalized for severe injuries from a nonaccidental trauma.Â  On October 16, 2003, in a formal order of removal, the family court found injuries to Javarusâ€™s brain, toes, neck, and leg occurred while in the care of another but under the direction of approval of Appellant and found injuries to Javarusâ€™s arm and ribs occurred while in Appellantâ€™s direct care and control.Â  The family court further found Brionica was at a substantial risk of abuse because of the severity of Javarusâ€™s physical abuse by Appellant.Â  The family court also ordered Appellant to pay monthly child support for Children in the amount of $248.00 with court costs of five percent.[1]Â  
On April 9, 2004, DSS commenced this action for termination of parental rights (TPR) against Appellant, John Doe, and L.J. Parker.Â  DSS sought termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (1), (2), (4), (6), and (8) (1976 & Supp. 2005) and termination of parental rights of Parker and Doe pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3), (4), (7), and (8).Â  
At the TPR hearing, Dr. William Lehman, an orthopedic surgeon, testified he treated Javarus on September 25, 2002, for a fracture of the upper arm bone.Â  On October 8, 2002, Lehman treated Javarus for skull and rib fractures.Â  He testified the skull injury led to significant and permanent brain damage, and he concluded Javarusâ€™s injuries were not accidental.Â  He further testified Javarus was two years old at the time of hearing, but functioning, intellectually and physically, at a six month level.Â  
Carol Tiedeman, Javarusâ€™s physical therapist, testified she began his therapy on January 7, 2003.Â  According to Tiedeman, Javarus had neurological damage and vision and hearing impairments and had been diagnosed with battered child syndrome and shaken baby syndrome.Â  She testified that Javarusâ€™s foster mother brought him to the appointments and did home therapy with Javarus.Â  She stated she had never met or talked to Appellant.Â  
Chrys Tuttle, a foster care case worker for DSS, was assigned to Childrenâ€™s case.Â  According to Tuttleâ€™s records, Appellant alleged she had five places of employment since Children had been in foster care, but Tuttle was unable to verify Appellantâ€™s employment history.Â  She opined Appellant had not demonstrated stable employment for a period of six months because she had not had any one job for a six month period.Â  Tuttle testified her records indicated eight residences for Appellant since Children had been in foster care, including a one bedroom apartment in Charlotte, North Carolina where Appellant had been living since February 28, 2004.Â  
Tuttle testified Appellant attended four of twenty scheduled medical appointments for Javarus, none of Javarusâ€™s twenty-three emergency medical appointments, and none of Javarusâ€™s one hundred, at least, physical, speech, and occupational appointments.Â  She also testified there were prospective adoptive placements available for Children and in her opinion termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights was in the best interests of Children. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
According to family court records, Appellantâ€™s child support began on October 17, 2003.Â  Appellant paid $20.00 on October 17, 2003, and $50.00 on October 31, 2003.Â  The deputy clerk of the family court testified Appellant was in arrears $3,054.80 as of the date of the TPR hearing.Â  
Appellant testified to four places of employment and four to five residences since the formal removal order.Â  She testified she would begin working at Mercy Hospital in Charlotte, North Carolina, the week following the hearing and she had been working at Presbyterian Hospital in Charlotte since June 2004.Â  She testified she worked at Burger King Corporation in Charlotte from February to June 2004, and she worked at Goodwill Industries from September 2003 to November 2003.[2]Â  
Appellant testified she gave Children toys, money, and gifts during visits and for their birthdays and Christmas.Â  She also asserted she had insufficient funds to pay the court-ordered child support because her employment with Goodwill ended in November 2003.Â  She further testified she wrote â€œa letter to Columbia to let them know what my status was with child support and to be patient with me and I would try to clear it up as soon as I could.â€Â  Appellant testified the family court records were incorrect because she had made more than two payments.Â  
By agreement, a written evaluation from Dr. Lisa Jackel, a licensed clinical psychologist who conducted a psychological evaluation of Appellant, was admitted in lieu of her live testimony.Â  She diagnosed Appellant with schizotypal personality disorder and alleged physical and sexual abuse. Dr. Jackel concluded that Appellant â€œis not currently or likely ever capable of appropriately caring for her children, financially, emotionally, or intellectually.â€
By agreement, a letter from Dr. Russell Hancock, Appellantâ€™s current psychologist, was admitted in lieu of his live testimony.Â  He diagnosed Appellant with adjustment disorder and schizotypal personality disorder.Â  He explained the difference between a personality disorder and a psychotic disorder.
 The guardian ad litem recommended termination of parental rights and found termination was in Childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  
On November 15, 2005, the family court judge entered a Final Order for Termination of Parental Rights, terminating Appellantâ€™s parental rights based on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4), (6), and (8).Â  The family court also terminated the alleged fathersâ€™ parental rights on the grounds of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (3), (4), (7), and (8).[3]Â  The family court denied Appellantâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment and for reconsideration, or, in the alternative, for a new trial.Â  Appellant appeals and we certified this case for review from the Court of Appeals under Rule 204(b), SCACR. 
ISSUES

  
    I.   
    Did the family court err in terminating Appellant’s parental rights because she willfully failed to support the children for a period in excess of six months, S.C. Code Ann. § 20-7-1572(4), or because she had a diagnosable condition that is unlikely to change within a reasonable time and made it unlikely that she could provide minimally acceptable care for the children, S.C. Code Ann. § 20-7-1572(6)? 
  
  
    II.   
    Does the termination of Appellant’s parental rights based on S.C. Code Ann. § 20-7- 1572(8) violate her due process rights? 
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The family court will terminate parental rights and free a child up for adoption if it finds that one of the nine statutory grounds for termination has been met and that â€œtermination is in the best interest of the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572.Â  The family court judge terminated Appellantâ€™s parental rights pursuant to three statutory grounds.Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-1572(4), (6), & (8).Â  DSS must prove these grounds by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 102 S.Ct. 1388, 71 L.Ed.2d 599 (1982); Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 496 S.E.2d 864 (1998).Â  When reviewing the family court decision, this Court may make its own conclusion as to whether DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence that parental rights should be terminated.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 356 S.C. 413, 589 S.E.2d 753 (2003).Â  The reviewing court, however, is not required â€œto ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Termination of Parental Rights
A. Willful Failure to Support
Appellant argues the family court erred in terminating her parental rights on the ground she failed to support Children or make any material contribution to their care for a period in excess of six months.Â  We disagree.Â  
Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) the family court may order termination of parental rights if:

  The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period Â of six months, and during that time the parent has wil[l]fully  failed to support the child.Â  Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care. . . .The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wil[l]fully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support. 

Whether a parentâ€™s failure to support a child is â€œwillfulâ€ within the meaning of the statute is a question of intent to be determined in each case from all the facts and circumstances.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 52, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992).Â  Conduct of the parent which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be characterized as â€œwillfulâ€ because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.Â  Id. at 53, 413 S.E.2d at 839. 
First, Appellant argues we should reverse the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights because the family court did not find her failure to support Children was willful.Â  Regardless of the family courtâ€™s findings, we may make our own conclusions as to whether DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence that parental rights should be terminated.Â  Cochran, 356 S.C. at 417, 589 S.E.2d at 755. Â 
Second, Appellant argues the family court erred because she made material contributions in accordance with her means.Â  Appellant asserts the two partial payments toward child support and her testimony that she gave Children toys, gifts, and money are evidence of material contribution.
â€œMaterial contributionâ€ is defined as â€œeither financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4).Â  Toys are not included in this definition and will not be considered by us in concluding whether Appellant made a material contribution to Children.Â  Â Â 
Children were taken into emergency protective custody on October 22, 2002 and were formally removed from Appellantâ€™s care on October 16, 2003 by order of the family court.Â  In eleven months, Appellant made two partial child support payments totaling $70.00, and she owed $3,054.80 in child support on the date of the TPR hearing.Â  If Appellant had insufficient funds to make child support payments, she could have petitioned the family court to reduce child support.Â  Appellantâ€™s failure to pay court-ordered child support or give a reasonable excuse for her failure to pay manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of Children to receive support, and is therefore a willful failure to support.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 582 S.E.2d 419 (2003) (affirming family courtâ€™s finding of willful failure to support where mother made some payments after being ordered by the court, then inexplicably stopped for 16 months, and although mother had caught up with her support payments by the time of the TPR hearing, the family court was able to look beyond the months immediately preceding the TPR action at the motherâ€™s overall conduct.); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 547 S.E.2d 506 (Ct. App. 2001) (affirming family courtâ€™s finding motherâ€™s failure to support was willful when mother made only one child support payment of $15 during 14 months and owed $490 in child support on the day of the TPR hearing even though she paid $457 to the court that day).
 The guardian ad litem and DSS case worker both testified termination would be in the best interests of Children.Â  Also, Dr. Jackel testified Appellant was not currently or would likely ever be capable of caring for Children.Â  Based on the above facts, we conclude there is clear and convincing evidence that Children have lived outside Appellantâ€™s home for a period of at least six months and during that time Appellant has willfully failed to support the Children, and we conclude termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights is in the best interests of Children. 
B. Diagnosable Condition
Appellant argues the family court erred in terminating her parental rights because she has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time and which makes her unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of Children.Â  We disagree.
Appellant argues DSS failed to present clear and convincing evidence that her personality disorder makes her unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of Children.Â  She also argues the family court erroneously relied on Dr. Jackelâ€™s evaluation because the evaluation is too vague, uncertain, and empty of evidence to support its conclusions and thus has no probative value.Â  
Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(6), the family court may order termination of parental rights if:

  The parent has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time including, but not limited to, alcohol or drug addiction, mental deficiency, mental illness, or extreme physical incapacity, and the condition makes the parent unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of the child.

The family court terminated Appellantâ€™s parental rights, in part, because she has a diagnosable condition of schizotypal personality disorder.Â  Dr. Jackel described schizotypal personality disorder as â€œinclud[ing] odd thinking and beliefs, suspiciousness due to paranoid ideation, inappropriate affect, odd/eccentric behavior, lack of close friendships and social anxiety due to paranoid fears, and unusual perceptual experiences.â€Â  From Appellantâ€™s personality test results, Dr. Jackel surmised Appellant â€œmay be more imaginative and her defense mechanism may be reliance on fantasy, neglecting practical matters, which may contribute to her denial of her sonâ€™s medical condition and permanent disabilities.â€
In light of her findings, Dr. Jackel concluded:

   [Appellant] is not currently or likely ever capable of appropriately caring for her children, financially, emotionally, or intellectually.Â  She can not care for her sonâ€™s medical problems if she does not admit he has any problems.Â  She did not verbalize any medical problems, need for therapies, or special medical care he requires. . . . [Appellantâ€™s] personality profile suggests that she is likely to be disorganized and she may feel ineffective in her ability to cope with life.Â  She may be more imaginative and not pay attention to practical matters.Â  She can not be trusted to follow through on what she says she will do.Â  She also has personality traits which may cause her to be prone to developing an addiction. . . . It appears that [Appellant] is unable to take care of herself never mind her children as she has not maintained steady employment or housing since her children have been in [foster] care. â€ 

At the TPR hearing, Appellant described Javarusâ€™s medical problems and stated he required around the clock care and was fed through a feeding tube.Â  Yet, the guardian ad litemâ€™s report supports Dr. Jackelâ€™s conclusions.[4] 
We conclude there is clear and convincing evidence that Appellant has a diagnosable conditionâ€”schizotypal personality disorderâ€”which is unlikely to change within a reasonable time, and this condition makes Appellant unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of Children.Â  The evidence shows Appellant denied the severity of Javarusâ€™s condition, had difficulty dealing with practical matters, failed to maintain steady employment, failed to maintain a stable home, and failed to establish she had reliable transportation.Â  See Orangeburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Harley, 302 S.C. 64, 393 S.E.2d 597 (Ct. App. 1990) (affirming family courtâ€™s termination of motherâ€™s parental rights, in part, under Â§ 20-7-1572(6) where mother had a low mental status which was unlikely to improve in the future, difficulty in caring for herself, poor impulse control, low frustration level, and difficulty responding to simple statements and directions and where mother had failed to maintain a stable residence--twelve homes in a little over two years--and could not manage her own finances).Â  Further, termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights is in the best interests of Children.
II. Due Process Rights
Appellant argues the family court erred in terminating her parental rights under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) because this subsection violates her due process rights.Â  
Because we affirm the family courtâ€™s termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) and (6), we decline to address Appellantâ€™s constitutional issue.Â  See Fairway Ford, Inc. v. County of Greenville, 324 S.C. 84, 86, 476 S.E.2d 490, 491 (1996) (â€œ[I]t is this Courtâ€™s firm policy to decline to rule on constitutional issues unless such a ruling is required.â€); see also Headden, 354 S.C. at 613, 582 S.E.2d at 425 (declining to address the issue of whether a motherâ€™s due process rights were violated because the family court terminated her parental rights under Â§ 20-7-1572(8) when this Court found clear and convincing evidence existed to affirm TPR based on willful failure to visit and support); Cochran, 356 S.C. at 420, 589 S.E.2d at 756 (same).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm as modified the family courtâ€™s termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights based on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) and (6) and decline to address termination under Â§ 20-7-1572(8). 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice James W. Johnson, Jr., concur.

Â [1]Â  In addition to the child support, the family court ordered Appellant to undergo a psychological evaluation and follow any recommendations made as a result of the evaluation; to complete additional parenting classes specific to nutrition and care of small children; to participate in individual counseling; to demonstrate suitable and stable housing for herself and Children prior to their return to her care; to demonstrate stable employment for a period of six months prior to the return of Children.Â  The family court further ordered that Appellant could attend any and all of Javarusâ€™s medical and therapy appointments and educate herself on the details of Javarusâ€™s ongoing care.
Â [2]Â  Based on check stubs presented into evidence, Appellant received compensation from Presbyterian Hospital for the pay periods ending July 24, 2004, and September 18, 2004; from Burger King for March 24, 2004 to July 15, 2004, and from Goodwill Industries for August 19, 2003 to November 26, 2003.
Â [3]Â  Those terminations have not been appealed and are the law of the case.Â  Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (unappealed ruling is the law of the case). Parker also executed a voluntary relinquishment of parental rights as to Javarus, which was filed on April 30, 2004, and took a paternity test which indicated he was not Javarusâ€™s biological father. 
Â 4] The guardian ad litem found, â€œIf [Javarus] is returned to [Appellant], she would not be able to care for him and be able to take him at a momentâ€™s notice to a hospital if needed since transportation has sometimes become an issue during scheduled visitation. . . .She is unable to explain the severity of his injuries nor the requirements needed to feed him, medicate him, [and] provide therapy for him or his day-to-day care in general.â€Â
